course.subject: COMP
course.name: Programming with C++
course.description: This course covers programming and data structures using C++. In addition to basic programming concepts such as variables and control statements, students will learn about arrays, pointers, dynamic data allocation, linked lists, stacks, queues, binary trees, recursion, and the basics of object oriented programming.
course.prerequisites: COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P OR COMP 1022Q (prior to 2020-21) OR ISOM 3230

reviews.author: TKah
reviews.comment_content:
Topics Covered

1. Introduction to computer programming
2. C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
3. Control flow
4. Functions
5. Array and structure
6. Recursion
7. Scope
8. Struct
9. Pointers
10. Dynamic Data
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue
13. File input / output
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite details. Taught by Li this semester. She went through all the lecture slides and gave many examples to demo the function.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fare
The labs are easy to get full marks.
TA will ask one or two questions during the lab section.
Both midterm and final are upper quarter, and A-
reviews.comment_workload:
one lab each week
3 PA
one midterm
one final

reviews.author: isinfinity
reviews.comment_content:
Topics Covered

1. Introduction to computer programming
2. C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
3. Control flow
4. Functions
5. Array and structure
6. Recursion
7. Scope
8. Struct
9. Pointers
10. Dynamic Data
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue
13. File input / output

The course is an introduction to C++ language, which is helpful if you never learned it. Compared to COMP 1021, a lot more work is required, so brace yourself.
reviews.comment_teaching: Taught by Li in the semester. Apart from lecture slides, she uses example programs to illustrate C++ concepts, some of which isn't available in course website, as well as drawing flowchats to explain the process of example programs
reviews.comment_grading:
Got a C+ in C++. Go figure.

The PAs and labs are easy to get full marks as long as you put in some work. I lost some points in PA3 because of an uninitialized variable.

The kicker is the midterm and finals, unlike COMP 1021, the exam is closed-book and bans computers, which is very difficult for me as I am used to working on code as I go, while the exam forces you to plan ahead. I did terrible in both.

Lab(1~8): 24/24 (Lab 8 not marked in my session)
PAs: 290/300 (PA3 is quite hard be careful)
mid-term: 39.75/100 (avg: 61.2)
Final: 47.75/100 (avg: 53.2)
reviews.comment_workload:
4 credit course so expect significant workload.

I am a LIFS major with minimal programming background, so takes a lot of time for me to figure out the code, but is relatively easy for labs and PAs. It took mw on average 2 hours to finish each lab and 4-6 hours for each PA.

For exams, just be prepared to work away from computer and try write something every question, get more marks this way.

This course will be quite useful if you never learn C++ related languages before, which actually give you a brief review over it.

This course is really different from COMP 1021, no more copy paste :< hand write la~

I was taught by Gary this semester, where he always offer some extra information or things related to COMP 2012 (a pair with 2011)

it will be great source to move to COMP 2012 :>

He will also involve some Piazza questions before the lesson, which can help us on understanding some extra questions :D
reviews.comment_grading:
Eventually receive a A+.

Doesn't requires full mark to get (Obviously requires some extra knowledges and fast thinking)

If you don't really have the mental power, you will probably fall into B range.

Lab(1~8): 23.2/24
PAs: 300/300 (PA3 is quite hard be careful)
mid-term: 94.5/100 (avg: 61.2)
Final: 85/100 (avg: 53.2)
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is sorta fine

Most lab can be done within around 15 min,
the last few lab can be done in 30 min?
(normally people requires 30~60 min ba)

(be aware of hidden testcases, many people shit from it)
(suggest use some skills like python/excel to generate random cases or ask for sources, I test and get a few glitches from it)

reviews.author: Zir
reviews.comment_content:
Basic c++. Most contents are easy to understand if you learnt Comp 1021 or else. However, Pointer is a little bit difficult.
No difficult algorithms. May include some basic algorithms like binary search.

reviews.author: Jaehee.h01
reviews.comment_content: Contents are very well organized and helpful if you pursue your career in any programming or data related fields.

reviews.author: Chibaboy
reviews.comment_content:
Topics: C++ Basic and Control, Function and Recursion, Array, Scope, Struct, Pointers and Dynamic Data, Class, Stack and Queue.

Topics Under Pointers and Dynamic Data:
-Addressing, heap
-pointer to constant objects, pointer to pointer, pointer vs reference
-memory leak and dangling pointer
-linked list, array and pointer, and indirect addressing
reviews.comment_teaching: clear and passionate
reviews.comment_grading:
lab (10%)
Assignments (24%)
mid-term (26%) and final (40%)
reviews.comment_workload:
The heaviness of the workload for a course varies from person to person, it might not apply to you. From my point of view, the workload is not heavy for a four-credit course.

First of all, the 2 hours online labs are one-by-one questioning sessions about your weekly lab code, which a TA will ask about how your code works. It doesn't last that long; you can leave after answering the questions or leave immediately if you're not picked for answering questions.

For programming assignments, a skeleton code will be provided, and you are only required to implement certain functions, which is only around 10 to 30 lines long for each function.

reviews.author: Porter
reviews.title: The exam is a reading comprehension.
reviews.comment_content:
Topics: C++ Basic and Control, Function and Recursion, Array, Scope, Struct, Pointers and Dynamic Data, Class, Stack and Queue.

Topics Under Pointers and Dynamic Data:
-Addressing, heap
-pointer to constant objects, pointer to pointer, pointer vs reference
-memory leak and dangling pointer
-linked list, array and pointer, and indirect addressing

Most of the content covered will overlap with prerequisite courses, but now do them in C++, except for pointers and classes (OOP). Classes won't be taught very profoundly as it is just a small intro to the next course, COMP2012. The main difficulty will be pointers and dynamic data; you can't escape them as they will appear in the programming assessment and/or final.
reviews.comment_teaching: PAPADOPOULOS's teaching is clear and passionate. The professor does have an accent, but it hasn't affected my understanding much.
reviews.comment_grading:
The weekly lab (10%) is short and simple, only to encourage students to try implementing what they learn in lectures.

There are three programming Assignments (24%), where the majority will get full marks. Make sure to check boundary cases for arrays and loops, and memory leaks for pointers.

For mid-term (26%) and final (40%), it is more of a reading comprehension, where speed is essential. Also, lab and assessment may be simplified and put into the exam as a question. Make sure to attend the paper check session.

I sit slightly above the mean for assignments, Midterms and exams, and my overall grade is B.
reviews.comment_workload:
The heaviness of the workload for a course varies from person to person, it might not apply to you. From my point of view, the workload is not heavy for a four-credit course.

First of all, the 2 hours online labs are one-by-one questioning sessions about your weekly lab code, which a TA will ask about how your code works. It doesn't last that long; you can leave after answering the questions or leave immediately if you're not picked for answering questions.

For programming assignments, a skeleton code will be provided, and you are only required to implement certain functions, which is only around 10 to 30 lines long for each function.

reviews.comment_content: Very interesting lectures. I like them very much.

reviews.comment_grading: I tried my best to study and review, but my grade was still not the best because there were too many excellent students in this course to fight for the limited high grades. And I guessed it may be easier in the spring term than in the fall term.
reviews.comment_workload: A bit heavy, but still in the acceptable range.

reviews.author: desmond fanboy
reviews.title: EZ for CS students
reviews.comment_content:
Starts off with basic C++ syntax: if statements, loops, functions, etc.

Pointers and references might be slightly tricky, but with some practice they should be fine.

Recursion is another topic where many people struggle. Try googling "recursive leap of faith," and follow that technique. Also useful for COMP 2711 or 2711H when you need to use recursion.

Stacks and queues are also relatively straight forward, try to solve some coding questions online to get a better sense of them.

If you have learned Java before, the classes section covered in COMP 2011 should be a piece of cake.
reviews.comment_teaching: I attended only a few of his lectures because I had already known much of the content, but I can say that Gary is a very passionate instructor. Occasionally, Gary would delve deep into the memory aspect of computing and show us what's actually happening under the hood in the memory level. Quite interesting and useful if you are a CS major.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is mainly determined by your midterm and final grades as most people earn 100s for their labs and PAs. Personally, I kinda screwed my midterm because I had spent too much time double checking the first half of the questions, and barely had enough time to complete the harder questions towards the end. The final was harder than the midterm in terms of difficulty, but as long as you can think logically and write your algorithms by hand, you should be able to get a high score.

Labs and PAs: 100
Midterm: 0.8 sd above mean
Final: 1.7 sd above mean
Final Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Not much tbf, but if you don't have much experience in coding I can see why some of the PAs might take a few days to complete for some people.

reviews.author: empathy
reviews.title: No comment at all
reviews.comment_content:
Contents are nearly the same in every semester. You can even self-study if you want, so I just listed some key topics here.
- C++ Basics and Control Flow
- Function
- Array
- Recursion
- Scope
- Struct
- Pointers
- C++ Class
- Stack & Queue
BE CAREFUL OF POINTERS! The topics before pointers are hard to study, as they share the same basic concept with other languages (eg. python). If you are a beginner in coding like me, I will suggest putting more effort into this topic and afterwards. (tbh it is difficult to achieve especially since you will be very busy at the end of the semester, so just try your best)
reviews.comment_teaching: I usually skipped the lectures. The only thing I can tell is that Cindy is a nice lecturer and I like her revision section in the lecture before midterm.
reviews.comment_grading:
I am a beginner in programming and I got a B+ in COMP1021 last semester.
The marking scheme:
- Lab 12%
- PA 24% (8%, 8%, 8%)
- Midterm 24%
- Final 40%
To pass this course, you need to have your total score greater than the overall pass mark X and obtain a separate pass mark Y in your exams. X will not be greater than 50% and Y will not be greater than 30% of the respective maximum scores. You will not know the exact marks of X and Y.

And here are my data and the related statistics.
Lab: 11.7 / 12
PA1: 100 / 100 (Mean: 90.67, SD: 16.84)
PA2: 100 / 100 (Mean: 90.31, SD: 22.88)
PA3: 0 / 100 (Mean: 71.31, SD: 29.60)
Midterm: 54 / 100 (Mean: 61.18, SD: 20.31)
Final: 31.75 / 100 (Mean: 54.51, SD: 22.32)
Grade: C
Just I mentioned before, I didn't have enough time for my PA3 and revision of the final exam due to my schedule. The lesson to me is to have better time management!
reviews.comment_workload: There are 8 labs and 3 PAs in total. Attendance is required in the lab session and there are a lab assignment and Q&A sessions with TAs. There is 1 lab session per week after the add-drop period. TAs will ask you questions about the lab (eg. explanation of your code, alternative methods, random testing etc) if you are selected, so you need to be familiar with the task. Also, don't be a deadline fighter with these assignments! You may need to search for more information online as the lecture ppt cannot cover all the cases. That's why the workload of this course is quite high, but anyway "Practice makes perfect". This course not only teaches the C++ language but also helps you get ready for programming and further COMP courses.

reviews.author: chronoaero
reviews.title: If you are interested in COMP, please give this course a try...
reviews.comment_content:
I am writing this as a first year student (and someone who needs access to reviews with course code >2000 badly). I am previously assigned to be enrolled in COMP1021. I have learnt some programming before, so I am a bit unsure whether relearning if else and loops from scratch again is an enjoyable experience...

Oh wait - out of nowhere CSE is sending an email at the start of the semester offering a C placement test to get a requisite waiver for COMP 2011. I'm interested in exploring what's in COMP anyway... so.. why not? I thought.

Anyway, this course does cover more than just learning a new programming language. C++ is called a low-level (?) programming language for a reason. Please expect that you are not only learning new syntaxes in this course.

[Contents before midterm]
- C++ Basic and Control Flow (Might be a repetition of COMP1021 (?), but now you have a slightly 'strange' syntax. They also have something called reference variable (they will usually put this quite annoying thing in the exam))
- Functions (Note that they are introducing passing and RETURN (some people might miss this) by reference here)
- Arrays (More or less like python lists)
- Recursion
- Scope (Basically which variable do you use if you have more than one definition of variable (yes, they might also test this in a very annoying way))
- Struct

(Note that function overloading may be included in the first half (as seen from the given past papers, but they did not include it this year))

[Contents after midterm]
- Function Overloading and Declaration (Yes, definition and declaration is different)
# Pointers (Basically the scariest and the main part of this course; they will also discuss how to manage memory and introduce memory leak here. You will start to understand how memory is allocated in programs after learning this part)
- Class (Note that they are also introducing something called constructor and deconstructor here)
- Stack and Queue

- New C++ features (not included in the exam this year, includes stuff like lambda expressions and stuff that might not really be used in actual programming. But you can still read them if you got the time)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Personally, If possible, I am not sure how to rate my instructor... I can see that he is trying to explain the topics and is really open for questions, but I find the explanation is a little bit confusing. However, I find that the slides from the instructors are really helpful, and does the job to help you understand the topic. I still come to the lecture to make sure what I might have missed.

I might suggest going to L(smaller numbers), e.g. L1, L2, L3 if possible, though. If you can't, you may try reading the slides more before class, and probably ask the instructors or post a question on piazza.

I find that the TAs for this course are really active and ready to answer your questions. There was one time when I sent a question via email to the TA about the PA, and I received a response in less than 10 minutes. The discussion on Piazza is also really active, you will get response really fast (except for the few days before the finals, which is understandable)
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading has a fair combination of coding with compiler and actually testing you on whether or not you understand C++ well i.e., code without compiler

Labs (12%)
Works this way:
Each lab allows you to get 3 points at maximum

You need to do the task given and send your code to ZINC before the deadline. Then, you need to attend the zoom session with the TA:

- If you are chosen to answer questions from the TA:
Your attendance in the zoom is worth 1 point, answering the TA's question is worth 1 point, and your ZINC grading is worth 1 point

- Otherwise:
Your attendance in the zoom is worth 1 point, and your ZINC grading is worth 2 points. (You might not want this when the lab is quite hard)

The lab usually takes about an hour or so to do. If it is a bit harder, maybe about two hours.

3 PAs (24%)
Basically lab but harder. Do note that for PA3, it is usually really challenging as they have pointers already taught in class.

Each PA might take about 3-5 hours to do, start early.

Midterm (24%)
Finals (40%)

My Grades & Statistics:
Labs: Mostly 3/3 except for one time I missed a testcase and got 2.8/3

PAs:
PA1: 100/100 [Mean: 90.67 Median: 98.55 Standard deviation: 16.84]
PA2: 100/100 [Mean: 90.31 Median: 100.00 Standard deviation: 22.88] (Yes, the median is full mark)
PA3: 100/100 [Mean: 71.31 Median: 80.00 Standard deviation: 29.60]

Midterm: 96.75/100 [Mean: 61.18 Median: 61.75 Stdev: 20.31] (Code on paper)

Finals: 87.25/100 [Mean: 54.51 Median: 54.63 Standard deviation: 22.32] (Also, code on paper)

Grade: A+

I suggest that you should come to the paper checking session, you may be able to squeeze out some points.
reviews.comment_workload:
Generally, I think the workload is ok. But saying that it is very light is deceiving.

Please remember to take your time to 'stress test' your labs and PAs. Passing the given testcases might not be enough, try to think about some crazy testcase that they might throw on your code and break it. Also, watch out that ZINC is running on linux and sometimes unitialized variables contains garbage value unlike and might produce behaviour that windows does not produce. Run your code on some linux-based compiler online and it will do the work. You might want to try github codespaces (my instructor suggested us to use this around the start of the term as some people may not have g++ installed). Try to squeeze out marks from the PA as this is a chance for you to program with a compiler.

For the exams, practice coding on paper once in a while. You may try something like LeetCode and try their easy problems on paper. If you can do it, generally, you should be fine for the test.

reviews.author: HU-HT
reviews.title: A bit hard, hand-writing coding exam is tough
reviews.comment_content:
Basics (Loops, functions, data types, statement)
Function definition
Pass by reference
Array
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointer/ Linked list
Class
Stack/Queue

These are elementary topics you learn in this course about c++.
I would say they should put more focus on class, pointer and linked list because they are quite hard to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is good. He is quite good at explaining in lectures.
However, TAs are quite not helpful in tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Marking scheme:
12% Labs
8% PA1
8% PA2
8% PA3
24% Mid-term Exam
40% Final Exam
In order to pass, your overall score needs to be at least a number X and your weighted mid-term and final exam scores needs to be at least a number Y.
X and Y are not disclosed but X <= 50 and Y <= 30

My score:
100/100 Labs
100/100 PA1
(Mean: 90.67, SD: 16.84, Median: 98.55)
100/100 PA2
(Mean: 90.31, SD: 22.88, Median: 100.00!!)
38/100 PA3
(Mean: 71.31, SD: 29.60, Median: 80.00)
94.25/100 Mid-term Exam
(Mean: 61.18, SD: 20.31, Median: 61.75)
81.25/100 Final Exam
(Mean: 54.51, SD: 22.32, Median: 54.63)
Overall: 86.16
Grade: A

I have never seen an assignment with median being the full mark (PA2).
As you can see, I fked up my PA3 so bad. Still, I managed to maintain a good grade with mid-term and final exams.
All the PAs are important since it worths 24% in total. One screw up in my PA3 cost me 5 scores in overall score.
One advice: Paper-checking sessions are seriously very important. DO NOT SKIP IT. TAs are very careless.
reviews.comment_workload:
Labs are quite easy to do. You finish the lab in 5 minutes, pass all the testcases, attend the tutorials and answer TA's trivial questions correctly, then you are done.
The difficulty comes in programming assignments PA. You need to fully understand what the code is doing, what you need to do, what given variables mean, what special weird boundary cases you need to consider, and probably more. Testcases given by the PA maker is not sufficient and you need to make your own testcases to test your code. (I fked up PA3 because the given testcases are freaking useless) Don't try to skip the memory leak testing. Zinc can detect your memory leak.
Mid-term and final exams are very unusual. You need to write your code on paper. (Who does that in real life) For me, I am fine at doing that, but I have heard complaints that it makes the exams harder. The length of the question is similar to COMP 1021. I spent half the exam time looking at the questions and trying to understand.

reviews.author: depressedcubic
reviews.title: A 1000-level course disguised as 2000-level
reviews.comment_content:
The stuff before midterm basically just 1000 level programming course stuff but with c++
After midterm have some pointer, linked list, stack, queue and some OOP stuff, but honestly still feels quite shallow, if possible take 2012h instead
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is quite nice, teaches at a good pace and is quite willing to answer question
reviews.comment_grading:
I fucked up lab, pa and final a bit

PA1(8%): 100/100
PA2(8%): 100/100
PA3(8%): 38/100
Midterm(24%): 98/100

reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly lab that take at most an hour to finish(except the later ones with pointer, a bit cumbersome)
3 PA with the first two being relatively easy, the last one takes quite some time
The bigger problem is perhaps that the assignment is not very well designed, u need to spend much time understanding the crappy logic behind it, and the testcase also is quite barebone, especially in the last pa where u can pass the given testcase then fail practically all the hidden testcase, so u might want to check your code a few more time or write your own testcase before handing it in.
The midterm is trivial and final is not that hard, but it is quite exhausting and the time is tight, practicing with the given pastpaper is quite essential for completing the paper in time

reviews.author: aAnonymous
reviews.comment_content: The content is clear. Slides are clear and logical, and full of details. Programs in lecture notes are offered. Labs and PAs are well designed.

reviews.comment_workload: For me, a 100% beginner in CS major & C++, the course is not hard. As long as you concentrate on all the contents in class, the labs and PAs are easy to get full marks. Full concentration in class is very effective and efficient. Overall, if you do all the things I mentioned above, it's easy to master all the contents.

reviews.author: Dade
reviews.comment_content:
This comprehensive C++ course delves into the fundamental concepts of programming using the C++ language. Starting with the basics, learners will gain a solid understanding of variables, data types, control structures, and functions. As the course progresses, it ventures into more advanced topics such as object-oriented programming (OOP) principles, classes, and inheritance.

One noteworthy aspect of this course is the in-depth exploration of pointers, a concept that can be challenging even for those with prior knowledge of C++. The module on pointers thoroughly covers their usage, syntax, and the intricate details involved in memory manipulation. Students will be guided through practical examples and exercises to master this critical yet complex aspect of C++ programming.

Throughout the course, emphasis is placed on hands-on coding exercises, ensuring that participants not only grasp theoretical concepts but also develop practical coding skills. By the end of the program, students will have a comprehensive understanding of C++ and will have successfully navigated both the foundational and more intricate chapters, including the challenging topic of pointers.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good! The instructor is very passionate and clearly explains the concept of the topic.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair but challenging, while obtaining full marks in labs and practical assignments (PAs) is comparatively easier.
reviews.comment_workload: Fair, 8 labs and 3 pa for this semester.

reviews.author: skim
reviews.comment_content:
Title: Navigating the C++ Challenge: A Major Struggle

Decided to dive into a C++ course as part of my major, thinking it would complement my academic journey. Little did I know, it was like stepping into a coding battlefield.

At first, it seemed innocent enough â€“ for loops, while loops, and the intricacies of C++ syntax. I thought, "Okay, this is manageable." But soon, we were thrust into the deep end, grappling with complex concepts that felt like they belonged in a coding expert's toolkit, not a major student's.

The lack of a gradual learning curve was glaring. Going from fundamental coding to the intricacies of C++ felt like trying to sprint before learning to walk. Even as a major student, it was a challenging leap. C++, with its reputation for complexity, proved to be a formidable opponent.

From tackling turtle graphics from python to wrestling with dynamic double linked structures and delving into object-oriented programming, the course felt like an uphill battle. A major in the subject didn't shield me from the difficulty; if anything, it intensified the struggle.

In essence, the course structure seemed to overlook the principle of learning progression. It's like expecting someone to master a language without teaching them the alphabet first. For those contemplating this course as part of their major, brace yourselves â€“ it's a challenging ride that might leave you questioning your coding prowess.
reviews.comment_teaching: I listened lectures from Professor Dimitris, and I must say, his dedication to explanation is commendable. While I find his teaching immensely helpful in grasping the concepts, the real challenge surfaces when attempting problems independently. Despite the thorough understanding I
reviews.comment_grading:
Despite diligent preparation, the recent exam posed unexpected challenges, leaving me feeling unprepared despite my efforts. However, working through past papers emerged as a saving grace. These resources not only boosted my confidence but also provided practical insights into the exam format and question types.

In the face of the daunting exam, tackling past papers proved invaluable. It offered clarity on content intricacies and honed my problem-solving skills. Though the journey was tough, the strategic use of past papers provided a sense of progress amid uncertainties. Regardless of the final outcome, the lessons learned and skills developed in this process are undeniably valuable.
reviews.comment_workload: Every week, the constant stream of labs and programming assignments is eating up a significant chunk of my time. It's become so overwhelming that I can't even find the space to hang out with friends or focus on other subjects. Struggling to strike a balance, it feels like these tasks are taking over, leaving little room for a healthy work-life equilibrium.

reviews.author: asssasasa
reviews.title: BIG DATA MINORS BEWAREEEE11!!111!!1
reviews.comment_content: I woke up one day thinking hmm maybe I should take a minor, something that would really help me branch out on the tech side. ok big data tech minor sounds perfect yay i was so excited to start my new journey which I knew was going to be tough since my only other coding experience was with COMP1021. So IMAGINE MY SHOCK when this is the next coding course I had to take. this course has a lovely beginning with cute little for loops ooooh while loops nice c++ syntax. fine w me. BUT TELL ME HOW we got here. they want us to be a human compiler but im literally just a girl in science doing coding for the second time EVER. THERE WAS NO IN BETWEEN. This is the type of content that takes months/years for beginners to learn and actually practice logic and retain all the information, but no they want us to fucking (sorry) coding experts by the end of 3 months. THIS IS JUST MY MINOR this is one of the most difficult languages to learn it's so unfair. from turtle graphics to fucking dynamic double linked structures with a hint of object-oriented programming. totally fucked up for big data tech minor there should be another course to just get the basics down. I don't think ust understand how learning works: ur brain needs some fucking time to process what ur doing.
reviews.comment_teaching: I did not rlly enjoy my original professor, so I watched prof dimirtris' lectures. watching the lectures was kind of a pain cuz its hard to read on the whiteboard and sometimes the projector would get cut off. but that's ok i will let that pass. i think he's a good teacher and for what its worth i quite enjoyed learning the theory.
reviews.comment_grading: hahahhaah now for the best part!!!! this course is filled with cpeg and cs and ddp kids and I'm just a big data minor <3 Id consider myself a p good student w a good gpa and i just wanted to challenge myself by doing something new. but no ust will just suck the soul out of u so don't u dare ever try doing anything outside your comfort zone! trying -> get fucking destroyed for trying <3 how did they think it was ok to pair me up w people who already have much experience with coding, and are used to using logic to solve problems (science has more memorization). when I was asking cpeg kids for help, even they were struggling with some of the PAs and mind u AGAIN I'm not supposed to get this destroyed for just a minor!!!! this course took away so much of my time, and my social life, and depleted my mental health, all for a shit grade or maybe a fail (exam in a few days). but not because i wasn't good at it or didn't try, it was literally too much way too soon. I'm a pretty fast learner and love learning but didn't get any form of support or grace from this course. super disappointed that they just didn't give a shit about people w minors and basically just put us there because there was nowhere else to go. do better.
reviews.comment_workload: it was a 4 credit course so i knew the workload was going to suck. i found the first 2 PAs manageable but the 3rd one is what threw me under the bus. i thought i figured out how to do and i passed all the initial testcases only to get thrown under the bus from the hidden ones. memory leakage was suchhh a big part of the grading and it was just super discouraging to try and then get ur soul crushed like that. and pls its not worth going through all that for what's supposed to be a minor. I was already taking on another 4 credit science course- LIFS3140 which was also one of the toughest courses for my major. was not a good combo and this comp course ruined both for me. never felt this way about any course before, always took accountability if I knew i just didnt try enough. thank u comp2011 for being my first ever ustspace review u deserve it.

reviews.author: ycohui
reviews.title: Learn C again with C++ syntax
reviews.comment_content:
The content is really boring, from a student who learnt C language already for years before. (and this semester we got so bipolar level of students. Fun Note: This semester COMP2011 students from MATH department had the fail rate up to 30%)

Which those students also slowed down the pace so much, we don't even have time to cover Queue, Stack and Lambda (not even in COMP2012 Fall23).

However, before rushing to enrolling to COMP2011 at Spring semester. I must told you that the grading in A range is really hash.
See grading for details.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia is a such good lecturer. She had adjust the pace of teaching in order to cater different students paces. Although she never use hotkey and sometimes messed up the code in demos, the overall lessons is great and not boring.

One extra note, she would happily to answer the questions from everyone, please feel free to ask her after the lesson, As the content is "rich" in terms of the syllabus, and the questions in exams is CLS (crazy).
reviews.comment_grading:
As above, although the grade distribution seems more lenient in Spring Semester than Fall Semester, I must warn you that the A-range is really limited and competitive. As there are many future CS/CPEG students with much prior knowledge taking this course in spring semester (aka me), there are limited A+ to give out.

For DSE ICT students references:
I got friends who studied Lang C in DSE with decent grade, still find a bit harsh for the mid-terms and finals. The final grade was B-range only.
Please consider before enrolling into the course.

Grades:
My grade are useless for references, you probably gets A+ in a 300 ppl course if you were several marks from the highest.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is really depends on your level of knowledge.

8 Online Labs & 3 Programming Assignments & 2 Exams

Labs are doable within an hour, generally. (Maybe not in the topic of recursion / pointer). Please expect 100% in all these Labs.

3 PAs, where the workload of the course came from.
Most of the time goes to debugging, expect two days or so to finish it for the PA2/3 for most of the students.
PA1: C++ Usage
PA2: Recursion
PA3: Pointers (Probably Linked List)

Exams, not workload(?)
The exam are "hard", you really need to know the details fully to able get the marks in the exam. This would drive the students who first studied in C++ crazy, as they need these to separate the tops students. Also, Import note: The exam is Pen-and-Paper, no computer allowed, please debug with your brain.

That's it.

61% of exam which include

and

36% final: Everything excluding binary tree.

5% of a C++ quiz which test the basic syntax of C++ and also your sight. Get yourself a pair of glasses if you need them. Do not mix "," and ";".

3 * 8% PA: PA are not easy for beginners. I spend days and days in doing the PAs. Give yourself more time. Do not do PA few days before deadline. Do not copy others' PA. They can check and the punishment is heavy (For the first time overall 13% of course grade would be deducted).

If you get mean you can only get B-/C+ because this is considered as major required course.

reviews.author: Leoml
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction to computer programming
2. C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
3. Control flow
4. Functions
5. Array and structure
6. Recursion
7. Scope
8. Struct
9. Pointers
10. Dynamic Data
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue (cancelled)
13. File input / output
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is very good. As the explanations on the new concepts are clear, it is very easy to follow the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab exercises 10%
Programming assignments 24% (8%, 8%, 8%)
Quiz on C++ Basics 5%
Midterm exam 25%
Final exam 36%

The difficulty of the exams are normal, but the short questions are tricky.

The grading is normal (similar to past), which means you need rather high for A-range and certain marks in midterm and final to pass the course.

FYI:
Quiz: 19/24 (Mean: 14)
PAs: All full (Mean is ~80-90)
Labs: full

Midterm: 70/100 (Mean: 55.4 SD: ~21
LQ: 39.5 Med: 55.8 UQ: 73 High: 94.5)

Final: 76/100 (Mean: 41 SD:
LQ: 19.3 Med: 38.4 UQ: 61.6 High: 93.3)

Grade: A-

As you can see, the scores of the final is rather low, but since grading is normal, getting LQ doesnâ€™t seem to be sufficient to pass the course. You also need high score in both midterm and final to get A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not heavy for a 4-credit course. The 3 programming assignments are not difficult and can be completed within a day. Just need to revise a bit before midterm and final.

reviews.author: ccccy
reviews.comment_content: Much harder than comp1021, of course because I skipped most of the classes, but there are videos on the website
reviews.comment_teaching: teaches and gives clear examples when explaining new concepts. have lab,hw,and quiz ,lab and quiz are easy but we have 3 hw ,the last hw is very difficult.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW and Lab 100%
midterm 39%
final 15%
and I get F
reviews.comment_workload:
last HW is very difficult and final is veryyyyyy difficult
The lab is completely useless, it's a waste of time.You have to wait for him to ask one by one, then answer the simple questions, and then let you go

reviews.author: JustinIsVerySex
reviews.title: Apparently this is a "hard" course.
reviews.comment_content: If you barely had to study for COMP 1021 you would have little to no issue with the content. It is really intuitive and easy to follow for the first half of the semester. It takes a tad bit more effort in the later chapters but it is nothing to sweat about. Most of the things you can just understand from a glance and only requires a bit of thinking to implement. Among all the courses I studied this semester this one requires the least effort.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia Chan is energetic when she teaches and gives clear examples when explaining new concepts. At the start of each lesson, quizzes the class on what they learnt last time to make sure they remember. Nothing really much to criticize.
reviews.comment_grading:
Consistency is key with this course with roughly 30% of the grade being assignments and weekly labs. The exam questions are only a little tough but your real enemy is time. You have to balance writing your code flawlessly vs writing your code quickly.


The only truly annoying thing is you have to write your code on paper, which is really dumb, because it is easy to make syntax mistake and hard to rewrite code once you found a problem. You have to really, really think clearly about your code before you write it down, or otherwise there is not enough space.
reviews.comment_workload:
The weekly labs are not difficult, only requiring you to have fundamental knowledge to understand how to do. For earlier labs you can finished them in >= 30 minutes, and at most, when lab content is about pointers, they can take 3 hours at most, 1 if you are smart about it.

The assignments on the other hand have many little tasks that require more thinking. There are only 3 in the whole semester, but you put in ~ 3 days for the last one. If you want to get full assignment points, make sure to allocate time because the final assignment is close to finals, where you might have a ton of other stuff to do.

reviews.author: Mineant
reviews.comment_content: It teaches the basics of C++. It also teaches some OOP at the end of the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think ok. The lecture notes covered all the required topics. I didn't notice any out syllabus items during the exams.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is fine. Be sure to review your paper since sometimes the TA or teachers might left one or two points.
reviews.comment_workload: Every week do one lab. And every 3 weeks there is a assignment. Most people can score 100 marks on all those assignments. But be aware of cheating, since they catched people cheating on assignments before.

reviews.author: Ahhim
reviews.title: Need to work hard on self study
reviews.comment_content: Include basic of C++. From simple things like For-loop, while-loop to the later harder topics like recursion and pointers. Pointers are really complicated and confusing in my opinion so better work harder on that before it is too late.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructors and TAs are quite nice. The lectures are not boring and the professor always explains with examples, which is easier to understand imo.
reviews.comment_grading:
reasonable grading. 8 Labs and 3 assignments all came with which specific tasks you failed so you can appeal if you think there is any mistakes

The Labs and homework are not that hard to do and you can always find TA for help if you do not know how you do. Just remember they are the easy source for scores.

Midterms and Finals are rather difficult compare to them. Since it requires you to write code by hand, I think time limit is quite a concern.
reviews.comment_workload:
As I mentioned in the previous part, there are 8 labs and 3 homework. The labs are all quite simple and will not take too much of  your time to finish them, even if you are not familiar with the topics. The assignments on the other hand are quite time-consuming as it consists of numerous of complex tasks.

You usually have either a homework or lab per week.

reviews.author: Surya
reviews.title: OK class, heavy workload for beginner programmers
reviews.comment_content:
The content is pretty easy to grasp but the exam will test more tricky and rigorous details of the easy topics.
Topics are something like:
C++ Basics
Control Flow
Functions
Arrays
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointer
C++ Class
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching was decent. Since it was online, it was hard to sit through lectures and learn. But the instructor was good. Used to draw out everything for us instead of just going over slides.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is OK, not too bad. Slightly below the mean got a C+.
3 Assignments (PA1, PA2, PA3)
10 Labs
1 Quiz (something like a midterm)
1 Final exam
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy. Almost every week there's a lab (kind of daunting if it's your first programming class after COMP1021). The first few labs are easy and didn't even take an hour but the complexity and time requirement increases quickly throughout the course.
     There were 3 major programming assignments. Not as light and quick as labs. Require about 1.5 to 2 weeks to finish if the workload is divided properly over those weeks.
     The final and "midterm" quiz was online on Canvas because of the online semester due to covid in spring 2022. The biggest issue for most people was time limitation.

reviews.author: Tonia
reviews.comment_content:
Covered in lectures:
C++ Basics
Control Flow
Function
Array
Scope
Struct
Pointer
C++ Class

Self- studied:
File I/O
Separate Compilation
C++ String

You can easily understand some of them after having COMP 1021. But the labs, PAs and tests are a lot more trickier than COMP 1021.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good teaching, but in a slow pace (in my opinion).
reviews.comment_grading:
Haven't finish the course.
But from the marks given for the labs, PAs and mid-term, just normal marking. The mid-term is harder than expected.
reviews.comment_workload: Ok, but may need to take more time to do the assignments.

reviews.author: C.C
reviews.title: Basic C++
reviews.comment_content:
Topics covered :
Introduction to computer programming
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue
File input / output

Mostly about general C++ , unlike comp2012 (the next course) you don't need to use extensive object oriented programming here , you just need to use struct struct struct .
reviews.comment_teaching:
lectures were fine , quite related to the exam . They bring you attention to various details in C++ which may appear in exam .

Special thanks to TAs they worked very hard to answer our questions and finished marking exams in just a few days !
reviews.comment_grading:
FYI:
lab exercises 10%
programming assignments 24% (8%, 8%, 8%)
midterm exam 26%
final exam 40%
total 100%

Almost all PA and labs around full mark , except PA3 ~65 (Mean : 71.99) , I quickly finished it and only briefly checked the output as usual , now I DEEPLY REGRET not treating PA more seriously QAQ ! please treat PA seriously !

mid term ~75 (Mean: 61.75)
final ~90 (Mean: 55.14)
A-

Not very competitive course (e.g. unlike comp2611 QAQ) I guess that was due to presence of many non comp students but you still need to work hard on general C++ programming skills !
reviews.comment_workload:
medium

lab attendance was via Zoom , TAs would chat with you for a few minutes and you can ask questions .

you can finish PAs within few days and labs within a day

If you go to lectures and labs and do regular revision you should be fine

reviews.author: i_dun_know
reviews.comment_content:
Basic C++

List of Topics
1. Introduction to computer programming
2. C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
3. Control flow
4. Functions
5. Array and structure
6. Recursion
7. Scope
8. Struct
9. Pointers
10. Dynamic Data
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue
13. File input / output

The challenging point in this course is pointer and dynamic data. You may skip all the lecture if you familiar with C++.
reviews.comment_teaching: Fair teaching, Dimitris explained all the concepts very detailed. He will pause and ask if anyone has any question related to the new concepts. However, he has a strong ascent.
reviews.comment_grading:
lab exercises 10%
programming assignments(PA) 24% (8%, 8%, 8%)
midterm exam 26%
final exam 40%

For lab exercise, it is very easy

For the PA, they will give you some test data but even you pass all the test data on zinc, it doesn't meant that you have done it all correctly.

For the midterm and final one advise is try to write some codes that a normal human won't write it. For example doing addition with booleans.

This course is highly competitive, so the grading is not good (personal feeling)
reviews.comment_workload: Personally I think the workload is light. Only 1 very easy lab nearly every week. All the PA will have at least 2 weeks to do. Totally enough time to do it.

reviews.author: deep_sea
reviews.title: Intro. to C++, requires hardwork if you have little background
reviews.comment_content:
Basic things about C++, including:
Basic syntax;
Functions;
Arrays;
Structure;
Pointers;
Class;
reviews.comment_teaching:
I took Prof. ZHANG's section. His style is like between just reciting the ppts and vivid demonstration, but at least good for me.
(+): Answering your questions patiently, professionally
(-): He has some oral habits that sometimes you need to pay extra attention to catch up with his idea.
The time of my section is right at noon, and I guess it is why some students don't show up, which makes the hall very empty. So choose wisely if it matters to you.
reviews.comment_grading:
labs 10%;
3 PAs 3*8%;
midterm 26%;
final term 40%;

The letter grade is probably greatly decided by your midterm and final term exams since there won't be a big difference between one another in labs and PAs.
reviews.comment_workload:
In short, if you are already equipped with fundamental, or even far more adequate knowledge for this first-step course, you will probably find the contents easy to handle and get a good grade. Otherwise, you have to work harder outside the class because there is a huge gap between lectures and exams.
Other than reviewing for exams, the 3 PAs are also a big part of the workload.

reviews.author: thedgyjas
reviews.comment_content:
Includes basics of C++, hard part would probably be recursion and pointers for non IT geeks.

Adequate past papers and exercises provided, do not have to dig for sources.

quite torturing to hand write code for exams :/

all lecture videos from all lecture sections are recorded and available on canvas, don't worry if you missed something out.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Mak is sometimes entertaining. He speaks in adequate pace with infinite patience to answer anything you've asked as long as you ask.

Answers emails quite swiftly, basically ask him anything anytime.
reviews.comment_grading:
tough.
labs (about 8 in total) took me quite a lot of time to deal with but counts only 10% nani?!
3 PAs 24%, 8% each (quite hard)
remaining would be midterm and finals

lab sessions are stupid, just hand in your work on zinc and answer a question asked by TA/ explain your code for about 10 secs biweekly on zoom.

Anyways I got a broken grade.
reviews.comment_workload: HUGE. Lab has to be submitted every week, with 3 PAs in the whole semester. Each lab takes about couple of hours to complete, while PA takes about a week for me as a person with not much programming experience though I knew JavaScript. Lab doesn't stop while PA is due, so you'll have to work on 2 things simultaneously.

reviews.author: StarryHe
reviews.title: Fair Course
reviews.comment_content:
Basic c++ stuffs.
At start of the course will be go through some grammar of c++ to let you get use from it after learning python, again learning some of the basic elements such as forloops, while loops, if-else, increments, pointers, classes etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very good.
Good pronunciation, very clear and well organised lecture, no problem I can state.
reviews.comment_grading:
~8 Labs(10%), 3 Assignments(24%), Midterm(26%) and Exam(40%)
Midterm and Exams consists of some tricky questions and long questions that ask you write code for a function, Midterm is fair but since Final consists of pointers and classes it is pretty difficult.
Grades are good. Quite satisfied.
Labs full mark
Assignments full mark
Midterm 92.2/100 (+1.2sd)
Final 72.3/100 (+0.7sd)
Mean ~55
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Labs are easy(~15mins), assignments are considerably difficult as each one causes you ~5 to 10 hrs each.
(10% of time writing codes, 90% of time debugging)
You should spend more time practicing codes if you want a better grade

reviews.author: Raina
reviews.comment_content:
1.Introduction to computer programming
2.C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
3.Control flow
4.Functions
5.Array and structure
6.Recursion
7.Scope
8.Struct
9.Pointers
10.Dynamic Data
11.Class
12.Stack and Queue
13.File input / output
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fine but sometimes overrun.
reviews.comment_grading:
LAB exercises (10%)
3 assignments 24%
Quiz 5%
Midterm 25%
Final 36%
reviews.comment_workload: There are one lab every week and three assignments. Each lab took about 2-3 hours. If you learnt c++ before it would be much easier. During LAB, there is Quiz section. It is easy if you finish lab. I spend about two whole days to finish each assignments.

reviews.author: Herson
reviews.comment_content: The course gives a glimpse of C++, with proper details. Through this  I can learn a lot.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cindy is a very patient professor who tells details of every aspect at a comfortable pace. Her teaching is a great fit for me.
reviews.comment_grading: I got almost in every lab and assignment full marks which is just what most students in this course do and got 81 in the final ranked at 11. Then I got A+, which means at least 11 "A+"s are given.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is proper and easy for me. There are one lab every week and 4 assignment the whole semester, with 1 hour per lab and 3-5 hours per assignment. It's far from a heavy workload.

reviews.author: Uras
reviews.comment_content: I believe the course adequately teaches a lot of basic programming skills and gives you a decent understanding of beginner level C++. For someone who has started out with python, a lot of the course contents will be very new and hard to grasp. Although the course mostly tests your coding ability and not your C++ knowledge, integrating these new concepts can be quite difficult. Some topics such as functions or recursion will be familiar, but they are already a big step up from what you will learn in first year courses. So, when topics such as pointers that don't commonly exist in most other languages come into play, most people have a really hard time wrapping their heads around them. Therefore I suggest not expecting a high grade from this course if you don't have any prior experience (besides introductory python course) OR you don't intend to invest most of your time into it. As a side note, if you are intending to take this course in the future, I highly recommend taking Java first.
reviews.comment_teaching: Although Professor Brian Mak has a nice way of teaching concepts quite well, I found his pace to be very slow. This was evident by the fact that we were many lectures behind all other sections.  His speech and his tone of voice are too calm and slow which personally makes it hard to concentrate for more than 10 minutes. But besides his pacing, he is actually very interactive with the class and explains concepts nicely, although sometimes he explains the same thing too many times.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is heavily weighed towards the exams. You can expect most people to get full marks on the labs, which in my case left only the assignments and the exams. Assignments were 8% each, meaning as long as you get 90+ it shouldn't affect your grade too much. Here are my grades for reference:

Assignments (Average): 95~/100
Labs: 3/3
Midterm: 91.5/100
Final: 80.25/100
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite light overall but very compactly distributed. There are 3 long Programming Assignments, but you are given 2 weeks to complete each of them. It might sound like a long time, but with the debugging it can take several days to complete which can be hard when combined with other courses. The assignments themselves were (for me) hard to get full marks (but not hard to get good marks) on because they are quite expansive and it is hard to get past every hidden test case (i.e. your code isn't smart enough to fit every scenario).

There are also labs every week which take around 5-10 minutes to complete. Free marks.

reviews.author: PakNin
reviews.title: Not a very difficult course
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers C++ from basics to detailed OOP. The first half of the course is easy, just simple indentation and logical thinking(if else, while, switch), which are similar to COMP1021. The second half of the course started to be a bit challenging, which covers pointers, class and stacks. They would be the boss in final exam.
Here are the content list.
1 Introduction
1-2 C++ Basics
1-2 Control Flow
1-2 Problems for Basics and Control
3-4 Function I
5 Array
6 Function II: Recursion  
6 Scope
7 Struct
7-8 Function III: Miscellaneous  
9-11 Pointer
11-12 C++ Class
13 Stack & Queue
and some self-study topics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia is good at teaching, her English is easy to understand, and various detailed example programs are provided.
The arrangement of lab sessions was not ideal. Some students have to sit in the Zoom lesson and wait for about an hour so as to answer Q&A from TAs
For me, I am quite familiar with C++ so I skipped most of the lessons after the first few weeks.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme is a bit different from 1021, which not only require your marks to be greater than a constant, but with this formula,
(total score >= X) AND ((weighted midterm and final exam scores) >= Y), where X and Y are constants.

Personally I think grading is fair.
Lab:         10/10 (10 Labs, only count highest 8 labs)
PA:           23/24 (3 PA, each 8%)
MidTerm:  24/26
Exam:       32.12/40

Overall:     89.12/100
Grade:      A
reviews.comment_workload:
4 cred course so workload is a bit high. Each week one lab starting from week 1, but students only need to attend every other Zoom lab sessions to answer Q&A(still have to submit lab assignment). The labs were easy, guidelines were provided tho not as detailed as 1021. Mostly can finish in 30-45 mins.

PA is difficult and time-consuming. They were released after midterm exam. They mostly test your understanding of specific topics(e.g. recursion, pointers, class...) but not copying sample programs. Mostly need days to solve it. (Goop is your friend, some nice guys may post hints there)

reviews.author: In ust I suck
reviews.comment_content:
The content is the same as previous years, you can check for other comments

But the exams are mainly about recursion and pointers, maybe more on pointers. So, please make sure you understand these two concepts well if you want good grade
reviews.comment_teaching: Brian is a relly good instructor, he explains all the concepts in a really detail way with examples. I think his explanation is definitely helpful for understanding the concepts, especially for abstract concepts such as pointers
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading itself isn't too bad for aiming B range, apparantly mean is B-. However, A range is really competitive, messing up one pa will most likely give you B range eventually(if you just score everything around A- to A).Here is my own experience.


labs 8/8 (mean 7.84?)

pa1 100/100 (mean 88.3)

pa2 100/100 (mean 84.2)

pa3 55.83/100 (mean 79.3, -1sd)

midterm 77.5/100 (mean 61.8, sd 23.5)

final 79/100 (mean 55.14, no sd is given but upper quartile is72.3 on canvas)

eventually I got B+, you can see the grading is really harsh for those aiming A range, please make sure you achieve 100s in all labs and assignments if you want an A range for sure. Considering the harsh grading for A range, I would say the grading of this course is quite bad, this is because of the ust grading policy :)
why don't ust gives more A range?? It makes me feel like all the efforts I have paid on this course were trash, nothing is meaningful
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is heavy even when talking about 4 cred course. You have labs every week, you have to revise the course materials and spend around an hour for it, each of them won't take you too long but it keeps to take you sometime every week.
For the assignments, they are quite tough, most of them spend me around 2 to 3 days. And the mean is incredibly high, maybe I am the only one who think they are hard><. Just make sure you have understood the materials of the chapter before doing it, otherwise your score will be similar to my pa3.

reviews.author: AHZHONG
reviews.comment_content:
Many topics are not too difficult. In my opinion, recursion and pointer are the most difficult topics. You have to write more code in order to train your brain to think recursively. Also, to understand pointers, it would be best if you tried to understand the concepts such as memory.
Week 1: Introduction
Week 1 - 2: C++ Basics
Week 1 - 2: Control Flow
Week 1 - 2: Problems for Basics and Control
Week 3 - 4: Function I
Week 5: Array
Week 6: Function II: Recursion
Week 6: Scope
Week 7: Struct
Week 7 - 8: Function III: Miscellaneous
Week 9 - 11: Pointer
Week 11 - 12: C++ Class
Week 13: Stack & Queue

Self-Study-Topic
Separate Compilation
File I/O
C++ String
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecture is not too dull.
He teaches a lot of concepts.
After listening to the concepts, it is easy to understand the basics of pointers.

reviews.author: Indo Mie
reviews.comment_content:
FUIYOH! What a Good Course for C++.

1. Intro
2. Basics 1, 2; Control 1, 2:
Basic syntax of C++, program control.
3. Function I:
Function definition, modular programming, passing parameter (PBV and PBR)
4. Array:
1d, 2d, higher dimension arrays, array definition, initialisation, C string (special type of char[])
5. Recursion:
6. Scope
7. Struct
8. Function III
9. Separate-Compilation
10. Pointer
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue

I would say first-half of the course is similar to COMP 1021. However, starting from struct, the content becomes progressively harder so be sure to pay full attention.
reviews.comment_teaching: Gary Chan is great at teaching and ensuring his students understand the concepts fully. He is willing to answer questions with great detail (which is extremely useful), teaches with fluent english (A major plus) and has a good pace. Covers important content adequately though towards the end of semester, it seems that everything was rushed.
reviews.comment_grading:

PA3 - 88.25/100 (mean 60.48)
Quiz - 30/35 (mean 20.47)
Final Exam - 84/100 (mean 49.68)

Grade - A+

Overall great content. Part 3 of Finals was very hard thoo. didn't even understand the question but still managed to answer with full BS and got some partial points ;).
reviews.comment_workload:
Gud Gud Gud.

IDK how some others do the PA For 4-6 hours, maybe they have had experience in C++ before. For me, my only experience was COMP 1021 and I got B+ hehe. PAs generally take 3 days to finish. For finals, I thought would get mean grade since it was tough. Fortunately, I did not mess my any of the easy questions and got generous partial marks in the coding questions. Quiz not hard, basic COMP 1021 stuff.

P.S. Don't forget to get enough sleep!

C++ basics
Function

First 2 weeks are very easy, just to get us familiar with the basic c++ syntax.

Pay attention to recursion, struct and pointer. They are highly related to the programming assignments.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cindy has a very good accent. Able to follow her lectures fluently. She is able to illustrate concepts and explain examples clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Lab exercises
10% Quiz
37% programming assignments
43% Final exam
0% attendance

Lab x 10:
Each week has one lab, force us to practice the topic learned that week. You would have to demonstrate your work to the TAs in zoom and answer one question from the TAs in order to score full marks for each lab. The questions are usually straight forward and easy to answer so no worry. Try your best to do it by yourself, or else you need to pick up a lot of stuff to prepare for the exam.

Quiz:
35 MC questions (mean: 20.47/35)
Take place in the first few weeks. Testing the basic syntax and functions (e.g. if-else, for loops, data types ...). A lot of tricky questions. Rmb to have a good time management cause time is definitely not enough to finish the whole quiz.

Programming assignments:
Have ~20 days to finish one assignment. Suggestion: Start the assignment at least one week before the deadline. Most of the tasks are not difficult in terms of coding but takes time to sort out the logic.

Final exam:
3 parts, each part has 1 short question that asks students to find the output of a given program. Follow by a long coding question. Suggestions: Do pastpapers. You can find some pattern by looking at the answers of the pastpapers. The questions are usually 2D dynamic array, circular linked list, binominal tree, class .... Memorize the patterns/coding and you can at least get some scores even though you might not know what the question is really asking.
reviews.comment_workload:
HEAVY Workload
Lab work each week + programming assignment each month

- For later topics like struct and pointers, the lab and assignment are very time consuming for me

reviews.title: ZINC SUCKS
reviews.comment_content: It is not so difficult for students who have programming experience. Although it may appear to be challenging appraoching the end of the course for students who have no prior knowledge in c++ and oop, i am sure you can manage to overcome it if you put effort in it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cindy is a very good teacher and she explains abstract concepts very well. You can easily stay above mean if you attend every lecture and spend 1 or 2 days revising.
reviews.comment_grading: the assignments are so damn difficult and time cosuming. The automatic grading system ZINC sucks. It can crush a hundred times, so you better start early.
reviews.comment_workload: lab every week, 3 pa. The pa can be very very very challenging. And ZINC make the work load 10 times larger.

reviews.author: Dicaprio
reviews.title: More Challenging than expected but still good
reviews.comment_content:
https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011
https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011_2021F
https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011_2021S
actually, looking at the course website directly yourself maybe better than reading other people's comments. (need account to log in but you should have registered one in comp 1021)(some past pages may no longer be available but you can change the year and term and find it yourself)

lab sessions need attendance. they randomize the order every time to check your lab assignment. Each TA check ~30 students and there are 2~3 TA (different sessions different number) if you are lucky to be the first one, you just need to stay for 15 minutes in the lab session. if you are the last one, you need to wait for 75 minutes in the lab session. if you fail to complete your lab, you need the whole 120 minutes.

I learned C++ for HKDSE ICT Programing. I got 5 in the end and this course is still a bit challenging for me.
Things not taught in secondary school/COMP 1021:
Separate Compilation (using multiple cpp files in one program)
Pointers (a type of variable that saves the address of another variable)
Struct (a user defined data type)
Class (a more complicated Struct with functions)
Stack and queue (they uses pointers to implement stack and queue and linked list)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cindy is a really good teacher. She explained the concepts very clearly and will answer your questions. I attended all lectures even though I enrolled in 9am lectures ðŸ™ƒ

The teaching team also uses Piazza, an online platform for us to ask questions. The professors/TAs/other students will answer your questions very quickly. it encourages someone as shy as me to ask questions so the whole teaching team is good.
reviews.comment_grading:
10 labs (10%)
Programming Assignment 1 (10%)
Programming Assignment 2 (12%)
Programming Assignment 3 (15%)
Mid-term quiz (10%)
Final exam (43%)

the mid-term quiz is quite early compare to other courses. (early March, ~week 4/5)
reviews.comment_workload:
10 labs, 3 assignments in total so there must be a lab/assignment every week.

Labs are simple c++ projects that will be checked during lab sessions. It can be finished in 2~3 hours.

the 3 programming assignments are a much bigger c++ projects. (they count more than mid-term) You will need to upload to ZINC, an online automatic grader to grade your code. You have unlimited trials but ZINC is quite busy near deadline (wait 30 min for grading report) There are many hidden cases so you might not get full mark if you don't check your code carefully. You may need 2~3 days to finish the assignment.

But when it comes to pointers, I need extra time to figure out how does it work and clear my concepts. This course mainly tests your mindset but not how much effort you paid. Albeit remembering subtle c++ ISO standards is also very important in quizzes.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Cindy explains the concepts quite clearly, as she uses an iPad to draw the logic out on the share screen for us to understand. However her accent may be confusing at times.
Most of my lab demos are handled by Vivian, but I have attended the office hours of various TAs when I am stuck in labs and PAs. They are really supportive and give a lot of helpful tips. I still remember one TA telling me about the idea of deep/shallow copy. The skills were quite useful, especially for students with very little programming background like me. I feel that the numerous office hours available to us really prepared us for harder applications, so you should go there if you got stuck as this is what they prepared for you.

(PA2 mean: 82.2, my score: 90)
(PA3 mean: 60.5, my score: 82.9)

My total score is 73.5/100,  which is a B+, much higher than the C+ I got in 1021. My grade eventually shocked a lot of my friends. Quite unexpected, glory to God!
reviews.comment_workload:
Was really heavy. The labs were still OK, but the PAs were really time consuming. It took me a week to finish PA3, and for both PA2 and PA3 I coded until 2am/3am for at least 1 day.

Try to find some friends to help one another through the difficult PA writing journey, you will feel much better with that. I did that through the comp2011 channel in a discord, as there are a lot of great coursemates. Piazza is also a great platform for you to ask for help.

BTW I actually walked through this comp2011 with God. Without Him, I would have gotten an F. All credit goes to God for my incredible three sub-grade increase, especially when I got stuck on pa2/3. I remembered when I got 90 in the pa2 I shared my joy in front of so many Christians and we all praised God together, and I sang the hymn I Need Thee Every Hour when getting stuck on PA3.

reviews.author: MISHA
reviews.title: Difficult Course
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to computer programming
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Separate Compilation
C++ Class
Stack and Queue

Self study topics:
File input / output
C++ String
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is sweet and takes a lot of interest in teaching. She is also very patient while answering questions. The lab TAs are very helpful too!
reviews.comment_grading: Very hard. Time management during exams sucks. The quiz had 34 questions to be done in 45 mins, out of which around 20 questions were about finding the output, which obviously take up more time!!
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload is pretty high. There are weekly lab demos in which you have to demo your code to the TA. As a beginner, the labs and the assignments were very hard for me.

reviews.author: jccy2106
reviews.comment_content:
List of Topics
1. Introduction to computer programming
2. C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
3. Control flow
4. Functions
5. Array and structure
6. Recursion
7. Scope
8. Struct
9. Pointers
10. Dynamic Data
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue

Self Study Topic:
Separate Compilation
File input/output
reviews.comment_teaching: Cindy Li is a good lecturer. She is patient at explaining the topics and answering questions. There are no tutorials in this course. Labs are only for demoing your lab work so no teaching is involved there. Piazza is very useful for asking questions and getting answers from students and instructors as well.
reviews.comment_grading: Very difficult final.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly labs. 3 Assignments. 1 Quiz. 1 Final exam. Overall I think the workload is moderate. Labs are fairly easy. Assignments can be quite difficult especially the one about recursion.

reviews.author: psc
reviews.title: Useful for learning fundamental programming
reviews.comment_content:
List of Topics
1. Introduction to computer programming
2. C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
3. Control flow
4. Functions
5. Array and structure
6. Recursion
7. Scope
8. Struct
9. Pointers
10. Dynamic Data
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue

Self Study Topic:
Separate Compilation
File input/output

The coverage is fair enough to understand the fundamental concept of sequential programming. Indeed, it required 2-3 additional class to finish all the topics. In generally speaking, it is more than a 4 credit course for those who don't have any background in C/C++ programming, but the topic 1 - 5 would be a easy topic if you already have learnt java programming and it would be a hard adaption if you only know python
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Cecia Chan is friendly, grounded and a nice professor. I often ask questions after the lecture, and I saw there were a queue of students would like to ask questions as well. from my observation, I think professor was very patient to answer each question. Sometimes, she would like to chitchat with us as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading would be a bit tough, as the mean is quite high for this year, it is hard to say a guarantee A if the total mark >= 85, but you would score A if the total mark >= 90 and A+ if the total mark >= 95

Criteria:
10 Labs: 10% (1% each, get participation marks 0.3% if you show up in lab session via zoom, no zinc submission required)
3 PAs: 10%, 12%, 15%
1 Quiz: 10%
1 Final: 43%

My Score:
Lab: 10/10
Quiz: 31/35
PA: 100/100,100/100,95.x/100
Final: 93/100

My final grade was A+
reviews.comment_workload:
3 Personal Assignment
The Personal Assignments are time-consuming, it cost weeks to do the debugging, and every single error could be disaster, especially the hidden test case are very tough to deal with. Sometimes, even the TA may not get the appropriate answer at first time

10 Labs
The Labs are quite easy, usually finished each within 2 hours if you don't want to try the extra part. But it may cost days for those who are not familiar with.

1 MC Quiz
The MC Quiz is quite tricky, and we cannot modify the answer of MC during the quiz(Online Quiz in Canvas), which is pretty odd, it is easily to lose marks in that part, but lucky it only count 10%, you still can catch up if you lose too some in this part.

1 Final
The Final is fine, as many questions are come from ideas of labs, assignments and the past papers, it is recommended to revisit those parts. It would be easy to go if you are familiar with those topic very much

Overall, I think the wordload is fair if you are very interested in programming or have fundamental background of programming in C/C++, otherwise you may get into trouble while dealing with recursion, pointer and linked list as well.

reviews.author: chk
reviews.title: Fair grading but useful course?
reviews.comment_content:
List of Topics
1. Introduction to computer programming
2. C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators

4. Functions
5. Array and structure
6. Recursion
7. Scope

I would say the topic after 9 are hard, the students who don't have any c++ knowledge before, may spent so much time to work with that.
reviews.comment_teaching: Actually, I didn't attend any lectures, I just attend the first 3 weeks and I wish to study on my own. Cause some of the topics are learnt. But I would say Cecia is a good professor, she is nice and friendly to answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading would be a bit difficult, I have some basic knowledge of C++, as well as the data structure usage and algorithm knowledge, so the difficulty is fair to me.

Criteria:
10 Labs: 10% (1% each, and you get participation marks 0.3% if you get the lab wrong but show that you have done some work)
3 PAs: 10%, 12%, 15%
1 Quiz: 10%

My Score:
Lab: 10/10
Quiz: 28/35
PA: 98/100,100/100,90.91/100
Final: 54/100

My final grade was B+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is fucking high, I still remember some of my PA, I spent almost a week working with that, and sleep at 4 am. It's really crazy. Also, some of the lab exercises are quite heavy.

And I hate writing code with a pen.

she teaches very slow and very boring. she tried to make it interactive but it really ends up boring and monotone.
she keeps emphasizing to redo all the assignments so that you can get a glimpse of coding which is pretty nice. but overall, i find it boring and slow.

programming assignments (3) - 37%
