reviews.author: wzk
reviews.comment_content:
Very brief intro of c++ (but most of the stuff is not unique in c++ but also in c).

I think the hard parts for many are pointer and recursion. If you understand these two well, I'm sure you will not be that bad.
reviews.comment_teaching: Although I attended the lectures only before Nov, I still watched the remaining recordings before the exam came. I'm here to say that Cecia is actually a pretty nice teacher for teaching c++. She won't be that active like Desmond but she still provides plenty of examples and introduces concepts clearly, at least I think it is enough for me.
reviews.comment_grading:
I forgot the grading scheme and pls see other comments.

Just for personal experience, I get 2 out of 3 assignments full, 1 with mean, nearly full in quiz and about 1.5sd? (I cant recall) higher in the final exam and got A.

So its grading is fair....
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload fully depends on very-week lab and 3 assignments.
The lab projects are not difficult but in average took me 3 to 4 hrs to due with each.

The assignments were designed by different TAs, so you should expect a big difference in their difficulties.
For me, easier assignment was likely taken me 3 to 4 half days. While the harder one, I started 3 full days before the ddl but I couldn't finish it. My stronger friends needed 4 to 5 full days to get it done. (of course the debugging carried on to the last minute).
So do the assignment earlier if you are not that confident with your algorithm and coding ability.

reviews.author: Khushi Chawla
reviews.comment_content:
List of Topics
1. Introduction to computer programming
2. C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
3. Control flow
4. Functions
5. Array and structure
6. Recursion
7. Scope
8. Struct
9. Pointers
10. Dynamic Data
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue
13. File input/output

Although Class is covered only in the last few lectures in the semester, but a huge part of it is covered in the final exam, so prepare Class well.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Cindy is really good, she explains the stuff well, and you could go ask her questions after the lectures and even during the lectures, she appreciates any question. I personally found professor Cindy's teaching better than Professor Cecia's, but again it's your personal preference, they both have good knowledge about the subject.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading would be a bit difficult for you if you do not have a COMP background (For me, I have some basic knowledge of C++ and had done data structures by myself before applying for the course)

Criteria:
10 Labs: 10% (1% each, and you get participation marks 0.3% if you get the lab wrong but show that you have done some work)
3 PAs: 10%, 12%, 15%
1 Quiz: 10%
1 Final: 43%

My Score:
Labs: 10/10
PA1: 100/100; PA2: 98/100; PA3: 96.45/100
Quiz: 33/35 (weightage was 10%)
Final: 58/100 (Mean was 45 around, SD: 16?)

Ended up getting A-
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty high. The labs are not time-consuming if you have good coding background, they take 2-3hours to finish. But, the PAs on the other hand is very time-consuming. PA1 was very easy compared to the other 2, PA2 was the most complex one as it involved recursion and PA3 was simple but lengthy.
The Quiz is not difficult but you could be short on time. The final was a bit tricky because we literally had to write down codes on paper, so you wouldn't know if you made a mistake somewhere, and you don't have enough time to review every single question (just try doing the sample papers by yourself before the final exam)

reviews.author: LuckyTiger
reviews.title: Highly biased and critical review sorry
reviews.comment_content:
Sorry, but I am going to be highly biased and leave a critical review here, because a lot of reviews here make it seem like it's a pretty normal course. However, I am going to speak from the perspective of an average student who got a B in COMP1021 and had no prior experience in C++ before this course. I also have a victim mindset from this course.

This semester they didn't go through in detail the 'basic' lecture notes because apparently, people were complaining that it was apparently too boring. If I remember correctly, they told us to self-read these lecture notes one at a time before each next lecture and skimmed through during lecture time.

http://2011video.cse.ust.hk/videos/list.html

People may question why I went through these videos, but the lecture notes are almost the same and it's from about 10 years ago. 10 years ago Prof Mak took 5+ hours of quality lecture time to introduce C++ while these instructors told us to read it. I guess I am being dramatic because these beginner materials are not hard at all and they did go through it briefly. Oh well, but there's more shit to self-study later on.

The other lecture topics, aside from those in the link

Problems for Basics and Control
Function I
Array
Function II: Recursion
Scope
Function III: Miscellaneous
Separate Compilation
Struct

Pointer
A YouTube video single-handedly made me understand linked list, a sub-topic of this pointer topic.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o5wJkJJpKtM&ab_channel=PaulProgramming

C++ Class
Stack & Queue

Self Study Topics ( for one lab ) ( not tested in exam )
File I/O
String

For each had optional tutorials.
For me I attended both simultaneously because of time management problems, but they weren't that helpful either. But I don't know, the information given in the lecture notes were not that helpful for the lab either.
reviews.comment_teaching:
To be honest, Professor Li is may be passionate. If you think about some instructors, they are indeed capable enough to transmit this curiosity and passion to students. My opinion: Professor Li unfortunately did not have this effect on me.

An immense number of times in lectures, she would go on and on about some part. Her monologues were detailed, but not concise. One thing that would tremendously improve her lecture is live speech-to-text conversion because my attention span could not remember the run-on sentences that she articulated with. She does have a plethora of knowledge to share.

A fact: at the last class, there were less than 10 students in the face-to-face lectures. Around 15 students on zoom. And I still wonder to this day how the were the other 65 students were doing.

I honestly did not know how to attend her lectures for the first half of the semester. After continuous effort going to lectures with a notebook and pen, seeking to draw some clear points being productive and shit... nearing the end of sem, I just sat and listened to her talk. It was actually much better because I got to at least focus on her words more clearly.

It seems like they are recording the lecture but they are not published. Then what's the point of recording it??
Please, I beg you, please, can you please, could you just make it easier for students to access these  information not just for students who are not in HK if you recorded it please?

An D to the teaching at the end because of the culture that they spread, which is honestly not even about plagiarism but about collaboration. They are so strict with plagiarism that they don't allow you to get explicit help from anyone in this course, which sucks, because I was stuck at certain tasks for days. Collaboration is pretty much discouraged. I mean, truth be told, it didn't really affect me because I had no friends but at the same time, I felt very reluctant to ask for help as I thought the help I would get would not be specific enough or whatever. I felt isolated. My opinion.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading? I don't have anything to say. It's fair, for the ability you show, not necessarily the time you spend. That is sort of true with every course and that's no revelation.

I legit couldn't care any less about the so called competition in this course because the only competition there is, is for those smart people who wanna get A-range. I just wanted to get a B or a C.

Most of the contents of the exam seems to focus on the big, later lectures including pointers, stack/queue, class, struct. Recursion and array are  important too. The broadness of topics is actually not bad.

Realistic stats

Quiz 25/35 Mean: 27 or 28
Finals 26/100, mean: 49/100 or something.

Assignments
PA1 88/100, mean 88/100
PA2 59/100, mean 71/100
PA3 88/100, mean 84/100

Every semester, they make 1 or 2 of the PA more difficult/easier or whatever. PA2 is harder this year.

Lab
10/10

Grade I got: C

It's not bad actually, I thought I would be given an F after that finals. I don't even know how you would study for finals. For me, I spent 60% of time revising the lecture notes and going through the examples inside and 40% doing 2 past papers so don't do that.
reviews.comment_workload:
I remember in this semester spending like 2 good days trying to do that self-study lab and still not being able to complete it. The main problem with me is that I did not try hard to seek for help so

TIP: Use the piazza when you need it. Go to office hours if you are truly stuck. The first time I got into office hours, the TA was not strict about straight out giving me solution for first task of a lab.

I remember in this semester spending 5 days to do PA2, that seemingly other people writing these reviews can do within 3 days. Yet I could not finish that assignment and I got 59/100. Fact: I went to counselling because of the hopelessness I suffered while doing the PA2. Fact: When I looked at the answer to PA2. I had two thoughts:

1. What is this?
2. I am satisfied because I would never be able to think of such a complicated solution.

TIP: TO be fair, considering you start really early when the PA is given out, like 2-3 days after it's published, maybe you could finish the PA without so much pressure.

reviews.author: ctliaj
reviews.comment_content:
In general
Basics: if statement/ for loop/ while loop, scope/ datatypes/ struct/ OOP
Concept: Recursion, Pointer, implementation of data structures (linked list, stack, queue, and Binary tree)

The harder topic in the course is Pointer, which took a big part in my final exam. For those who want to prepare in advance, I recommend starting with Pointer.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It was surprising that she was able to go through all the lecture materials so much in-depth and demonstrate all the programs given on the course website multiple times only in a period of three months. Some say she'd explain the fundamental even the trivial concepts too much in detail thus making the course boring.

Other than that, there is nothing wrong with the way she teaches. It was quite helpful and concise actually, even for students with no prior programming experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab exercises (10%) 10/10, once every week

3 programming assignments (10%, 12%, 15%)
pa1 74/100 (Manipulating elements in an array),
mean 88/100
Comment: Not hard at all. The -36 marks was me forgetting to delete a line of printout.

pa2 100/100 (Finding the longest path with recursion)
mean 71
Comment: Hardest of all. Regardless, the majority got 100/100.

pa3 100/100 (Doubly linked list represented by a train)
mean 84
Comment: Easier than pa2. Very straightforward.

Quiz (10%) 31/35. Include only the basics written above up to the topic of Datatypes. The hardest part for me was to trace the program.

Final exam (43%) 56.5/100. Most questions were about OOP with pointers. It was mostly about solving problems rather than just coding. One of mine was a question from Leetcode. Nevertheless, doing every past paper on the course website and reading the exam questions carefully should be sufficient for getting >70%.

Overall ~77/100 B+

People with overall ~mean get B. The cut-off is probably at 80% like most of the other comp courses.
reviews.comment_workload:
One assignment per month. Although each can be done in probably less than a week.

Ten labs in total, a couple of hours should be enough.

I think the workload is pretty light!

reviews.comment_workload:
Very high workload compare to COMP1021. You have to implement the code not just fill in the blank like in COMP1021. There are 10 weekly labs and 3 programming assignments. The programming assignments are considerably harder than the labs. However, the labs are not that simple if you don't understand the content well enough. If you are really desperate, you can find some help on the internet.
Lab 1- Intro
Lab 2- Control Flow, Basics II, Control II
Lab 3- Functions
Lab 4- Array
Lab 5- File I/O
Lab 6- Recursion
Lab 7- Separate Compilation, Function Overload, and Default Arguments
Lab 8- Struct array and Pointer array
Lab 9- Linked List
Lab 10- Classes
PA 1- Arrays
PA 2- Recursion
PA 3- Pointer

reviews.author: Mavis1
reviews.comment_content: Learning the basic C++ language and basic ideas of progrmming concept, such as recurrsion and linked list. Quite fun.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is zoom lecture and the instructor explains clearly and running many programs as example. If you follows her every lectures, the idea should be clear.
reviews.comment_grading:
My quiz(10%) got (26/35), which is slightly lower than mean(28/35).
My all labs(10%) are (3/3), almost everybody got full la.
My 1st PA(10%) is (88/100) and mean is (66.4/100).
My 2nd PA(12%) is (49.4/100) and mean is (85/100).
My 3rd PA(15%) is (54.92/100) and mean is (81.54/100).
My final(43%) is (67/100) and mean is (47.29).
And my final grade is B-.

The PAs are suffering and have high proportion of grade (10%,12%,15%). Therefore, if you are taking this course, don't do that just 3 days before that or life will be so sad.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is large. Every weeks' lab will take you some time to do but not too difficult if you follow every lectures. However, if you didn't attend then you can still spend an overnight to finish it right before your lab schedule.

The PA is the greatest workload. It appears to be quite easy for the first one. However, it is a trap that the 2nd and 3rd one are so troublesome. If you start too late then will be so gg.

For the midterm and final exam, if you spend 1 whole day watching back the lecture (if you didn't attend) and 1 whole day doing the past paper then should be ok.

The PA!!!! Everytime the deadline coming, you will be nervous and the mind can't function and end up you don't know what you are doing and the problem is the PAs can't "reference" from your dear friend!!!!! And for the lab, you may ask for your friend "opinion" but better do it yourself to know what is happening. And better attend the lectures or you will spend overnight struggling, training your persistence and thinking about your life.

reviews.author: CCC_ccc
reviews.comment_content: basic (but complicated) things about c++
reviews.comment_teaching: not bad, at least the slides are really good as review material.
reviews.comment_grading: the grading was reasonable. I got quiz: 32/35, lab: 8/10, pa1: 86/100, pa2: 97/100, pa3: 97/100, and final around 10 points above mean, and finally it's a B+

reviews.author: shitMan
reviews.comment_content:
The topics before pointer is basically covered in COMP1022P(java programming), which are quite simple if you took 1022p seriously.

The rest of the topics: pointer, linked list, binary tree, dynamic memory allocation, class, stack and queue. These are what will be mostly included in the final exam. They take you time!! Be prepared!!
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia's teaching is quite decent. Although it may be a bit simple for those who already have C++ background, she teaches the basic stuff quite detailedly and always give some confusing small question during the lecture(so don't skip lecture). Also, Cecia is quite nice that she would spend a lot of time after class to help you with your PAs, labs, etc..
reviews.comment_grading:
PA1: array, 10%, I got 96/100
PA2: recursion, 12%, I got 94/100(PA2 is usually very difficult, it took me a lot of days and hair...)
PA3: doubly linked list, 15%, I got 97/100
quiz: 10% I got 34/35, 35 MCs, very basic concepts and ask you output given a piece of code, do the self-test quiz in the course web page will help
labs: 10%, I got full marks, they are very simple, just take you one to two hours per week
final exam: 43%, I got 83.5/100, mean is 50 something, final exam is difficult, time consuming and preparation needed, don't think you can finish all of them or they are all in your grasp, be strategic!

Finally my overall is 91/100, got A+. I heard that as long as your overall is above 80, you would can an A range, not bad.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is large. Be prepared of everything.... PAs, exams...

PAs need time to think, plan, implement and debug, don't be ddl fighter, there are a lot of last minute bugs!

Exam can be well prepared by doing simple question about linked list and binary tree on leetcode, class question are usually simple yet they will put in at last!!! So again, be strategic !

reviews.author: I Love Flutter
reviews.title: Say No To Plagiarism and Do Some LeetCode (https://leetcode.com/)
reviews.comment_content:
I will talk about my background first. I am an associate student who already have C++ background (without pointer) and Data Structure in Java. That's why the course was pretty easy for me.
You can check the content from others feedback which is very common teaching scope of any fundamental programming course in any universities.

I kinda fucked up my online MC quiz because I thought we could only compile the code with human brain (not with paper) and go back to previous questions (the canvas system didn't allow students to go back to previous submitted questions). So, I just finished the test within 30 mins out of 45 and waited there for freaking 15 mins rethinking my mistakes. Fuck man. While I was waiting there I looked up the Zoom Camera and others students were all doing the compilation on the paper.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Li is a very good teacher. Helpful and willing to explain the details in deep. Although many students complained about her accent, I think it wasn't a big deal as I found it easy to understand what she taught and many foreign students do agree. Students should really train themselves to listen to people with accent. Those Indians, Russians and Chinese online videos on YouTube will be extremely useful in your later career if you want to do self-learning or watch extra content of your courses. And their accent problem are like 20x more serious than Dr. Li. Think about it. ;)
The whole teaching team especially Wallace and other 3 TA who designed the PAs were willing to spend their time responding our stupid questions and jokes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz - C++ syntax, error finding, looping compilation
------------------------------------------------------------------
PA1 - Array and Function (Leetcode Question ==)
***Update (1/30): I think the question is the same as Leetcode Daily Challenge 30/1 Rotate Array
Link: https://leetcode.com/problems/rotate-array/
------------------------------------------------------------------
PA2 - Recursion and Function (Pretty hard if you are not familiar with recursion)
------------------------------------------------------------------
PA3 - Double Linked List and Pointer
------------------------------------------------------------------
Final - It gotta be damn long:
1) Error findings
2) Code Compilation on Recursive functions
3) Tree Drawing, Code Compilation on Recursive functions
4) Pointers & Dynamic Array - deference of deference, Pointer of Array? I forgot the details of this question.
5) Recursion on Linked List
    a) https://leetcode.com/problems/add-two-numbers/
    b) https://leetcode.com/problems/reverse-linked-list/ (USE RECURION)
    c) Forgot
6) Class and methods
------------------------------------------------------------------
Quiz: 26/35
PA1: 0/100 (Originally 98/100, GitHub Issue, you know if you know)
PA2: 48.9/100 (4 deadline crashed together so I gave up 2 main tasks)
PA3: 92.8/100
Lab: 10/10
Final: 60.5/100 (It is a easy one I think, I didn't do revision on the Pointer of Pointer questions and others mistakes were all the simplest question :| )
--------------------------------------------
Final Grade is C+. I think it is reasonable as I have already lost 10% + 6% in PA1 and PA2 respectively.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of this course is acceptable but PA2 was a bit hard this year for students without legit programming background. Don't get hyped if you get an A in the stupid Python course which teach about Panda. Many students get A range in elementary Python course fucked up in COMP2011 and COMP2012h.

As mentioned in CONTENT section, I am an associate students so my study pattern is different form most of the CS students. I studied this course and Computer Organization in the same semester yet, this is not a good decision at all. The homework deadline of these 2 courses overlapped all the time with other deadline of stupid LANG courses. So, COMP2011 is a good course to take if your deadlines don't collide together. Otherwise, it might be a nightmare for you guys.

X and Y will be determined at the end of the semester but we may promise you that:
X will not be greater than 50, and
Y will not be greater than 16.

reviews.author: kkkph1
reviews.comment_content:
Topics covered:
Introduction to computer programming
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue
File input / output (for self-learning, not tested)

Honestly, this feels like a C programming course rather than C++ because it is literally really "late" objects.

Grading policy:
lab exercises 10%
programming assignments 37% (10%, 12%, 15%)
quiz 10%
final exam 43%
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is pretty good. Everything you need for completing the assignments and exams is covered in the lecture slides. The professor also gives some demos in the lecture that enhances your understanding of the concepts.
Try not to skip lectures if you are not familiar with C programming. Especially towards the end of the semester. The topics are heavily covered in the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz stats:
mean 27.9/35
sd 4.09

Final stats:
mean 48.26
median 48
sd 20.59
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty light if you already knew C. We have weekly lab assignments that take about an hour to finish (on average).

The three PAs are given about two to three weeks each for you to finish. You can definitely finish is if you start early.

reviews.author: jacccyh
reviews.title: Average workload if you familiar with C++
reviews.comment_content:
Fundamental programming concepts
I would say this is the most important CS course (2012 as well) in 4 years

Knowledge in this course are highly related to your future career as a developer

So don't skip it :)

----- Contents -----

reviews.comment_teaching:
All prof. TA's are nice and willing to answer questions

Lot of demonstration on class to help clearing concepts

Have labs every weeks, for clearing concepts and checking lab answers

Good grade
Below mean on quiz still got B

reviews.comment_workload:

reviews.author: yeahmoee
reviews.title: Pretty well designed course
reviews.comment_content: The content is very well-rounded.  At the start of the course, you will be taught the very basics of C++, then they will move onto more advanced topics such as Pointers and Class. In general, this course is a very good start for CS students.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cindy is an awesome lecturer. Her English is good. She gives interesting analogies to difficult ideas. She is also willing to explain to students after the class or in-office hours.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading weight: 10 Labs (only 9 for me due to holiday policy), 3 PAs, 1 Quiz, 1 Final

10 Labs (10 %)
1 Quiz (10 %)
3 PAs (~40 %)
Final (~40 %)

In general, this course's grading is pretty average. Getting an A-range grade is difficult, though it is not impossible. My suggestion is to start doing your PAs as early as possible, they are all very difficult, especially PA2 (recursion) and PA3 (pointers), and when it is around the due date, the submission platform Zinc takes very long to grade. The labs are fairly easy. The Quiz mainly focused on C++ syntax and control flows, and it is easy as well. The final is really, really hard though, it is an overview of what you learned throughout the semester.
reviews.comment_workload: You should expect to spend 1-2 hours for labs, and 8-10 hours for PAs (normally finished in 3-5 days). You should expect to spend at least 5-10 hours a week on the course materials. It is not that bad.

reviews.author: Tommmmm
reviews.title: not bad
reviews.comment_content:
Content is not that difficult for beginning learner of C++.
Most of the content should be handled well.
it is good for beginning the computer science.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor will answer all the extra questions from students clearly and patiently.
He is responsible and knowledgeable.
reviews.comment_grading:
lab exercise   10%
programming assignments   37%
quiz   8%
final exam    45%
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not large if you can catch up the progress.
There is not any tricky practice or assignments.
Most of time will be spent on the programming assignments. Some concepts need time to be digest. Starting the assignment early is suggested.

reviews.author: TTrum
reviews.title: Ok course
reviews.comment_content: Content is good and useful as a introductory course to computer science.  Good to have learnt python before coming to this because some of the concept can be carried over
reviews.comment_teaching: depends on the professor.  Mine is the female professor and she taught so slow and i always fall asleep but i guess she talked quite details
reviews.comment_grading: The homework is 10%, midterms 30% while the rest is finals.  if you have some programming knowledge then you will be fine
reviews.comment_workload: Quite alot actually every week you need to do lab and every a few weeks you will get the actual assignment

reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is great.

However, it is very difficult to get the A range as so much people are good at programming. In the last quiz and assignment, the mean of the quiz is around 28.XX/35 and assignment 88.XX/100.

reviews.author: sthiihts
reviews.comment_content: Basic programming skills and data structure as well as basics of OOP. You should understand the use of arrays, pointers, dynamic data allocation, linked lists, stacks, queues, binary trees, recursion after taking this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture: The teaching pace was steady. It was quite boring and easy to fall asleep after taking the lecture. But overall it was not bad. The slides and her explanations were clear enough. Most people can understand easily I think.
Lab: Just finish it before the day you need to demo your work. Then just leave if TA thinks there is no problem. There is 1 week to finish it. Not so difficult and able to finish in one day. So there should be enough time to prepare.
reviews.comment_grading: Should be either A- or B+ if the score of your overall assessment result is higher than 80%.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not so heavy in this semester since the assessments was changed.      No final in this semester. It was replaced by the fourth assignments.
Lab: 1 lab per week except the first two weeks
Assignments: 4 assignments
Quiz: 1 Quiz
Exam: 1 mid-term exam

reviews.author: Fong C.
reviews.comment_content: The slides were well-organized and helpful. Most of my revisions for quizzes, exams, and assignments were done using lecture slides.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was fine and understandable. The professor expected students to revise course material before class. During class, examples relevant to the lecture slides and ungraded quizzes were shown. It created a more "hands-on" experience, as it allowed students to directly realize what content they haven't fully mastered. Personally, I think this unconventional style of teaching greatly supplemented the lecture slides.
reviews.comment_grading: The assignments and exams were challenging, but not to the point where it is unfairly impossible.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is on the heavy side. A lot of revision after class is required.

reviews.author: chaer
reviews.title: Do not choose his lecturesï¼
reviews.comment_content: Since someone else had already posted the course contentï¼ŒI will not post it here. A brief review on basics and control for 3 weeks then moving on. Remember to focus on pointer, which is difficult but really important for no programming background student.
reviews.comment_teaching: This professor has a verrrrrry strong accent. You need to distract much attention on figuring out what he is trying to express although he actually teaches programming with lot of examples. Garyâ€™s lecture is a better choice.
reviews.comment_grading:
I received a grade of C+
Final exam needed full preparation.
reviews.comment_workload:
10 labs
3 PAs

labs just so so
PAs somehow difficult, especially PA3

reviews.author: Vegetable
reviews.title: Decent Programming Course as Intro to COMP
reviews.comment_content: Please refer to other posts for details. Remember to pay close attention to recursion as it is very useful on handling certain kinds of questions and occurs frequently in both pastpapers and the final of 2021_Spring. The curriculum setting is very fundamental and easy compared to similar courses in other school, so for the students interested in more advanced and challenging topics, you need to spend some time searching for exercises and projects yourselves.
reviews.comment_teaching: Special Credit To Cindy! The pace of her lectures is pretty slow honestly, but she can explain every single concept clearly and also weclomes any question at any time. If she does not remember the exact answer for some very detailed questions about C++ standard, she will reply you the answer after checking the relative documents herself. I am also glad that I get a responsible and patient TA on my lab session. The overall experience as a student of COMP2011 is perfect.
reviews.comment_grading: Please refer to other posts for details. I think the grading of this semester is pretty nice compared to past ones'. Getting almost fullmark on PA and Lab is a necessary but not sufficient condition for most students aiming for A+, unless you do a really good job on final. For the rest of students, don't get too nervous on final. As long as you do the lab and PA BY YOURSELF, I think at least A range is secured. In this semester's final, about half of students are below 40/100. Comparing it to the statistics of PAs, I have sufficient reasons to believe that a large portion of them did not finish the labs and PAs independently. As the exercises provided by the teaching team are far less than enough, please make use of every chance you get, not just wasting them by "Legal Communication To Other Students". According to my friends' and my scores, the overall cutoff between A+ and A should be around 87.
reviews.comment_workload: As I already said in CONTENT part, the workload of this course is pretty light as the lab and PA are really easy, i mean really. The time I spent on checking my PA submissions is twice more than the time spent on writing them (though it is actually not necessary). There is a special point worth being mentioned: write all your codes on txt file and force yourself finish them onethrough because in the exam, you have no opportunity to check your codes by compiling them and no hints about syntax will be given. If you cannot overcome the anxiety during the exam due to the above reasons, you may be crushed and get a suck score. In f2f mode, the coding part is very likely to be hand-written, which also take you some time to get familiar with.

reviews.author: ECream
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to computer programming
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue
File input / output

*File I/O is not included in the exam syllabus.
It's a good start for someone who wants to program.
reviews.comment_teaching: I personally really like Gary Chan's teaching style, despite having a bit HK accent, his English is good and clear. His diagrams about stack and heap are very clear, which helped me understand pointers quickly. He is also willing to answer students' questions. The pace of teaching is moderate, but actually slowed down during Pointers, because of how complicated it is, we used nearly an entire month to cover this topic.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz: me: 17/25 (mean= 19.13, sd = 3.64)
Lab: Not full score, around 9.33/10
PA1: me: 95/100 (mean= 82.24, sd = 24.20,  over 200 students within 90-100)
PA2: me: 91.89/100 (mean= 91.4, sd= 13.1, 313 students within 90-100)
PA3: me: 100/100 (mean= 73.37, sd= 29.4, 187 students with 90-100)
Final: me: 33/100 (mean= 40.28, sd= 21.32, 205 students above mean)
Total:  around 65/100
Letter Grade: B-

I am not a good quick thinker, not very experienced in programming and not fully prepared for the final exam, so I did relatively poorly in exam and quiz.

Was expecting C+, but got 1 higher subgrade, I am happy about that already, as this course is hyper competitive.
reviews.comment_workload:
I guess it's reasonable for a 4 credit course. If it was a 3 cred course, I would give an E.

Nearly every week, you need to hand in a lab homework which cost you a few hours per week. And throughout the semester, you got to do 3 Programming assignments (PAs), each of which gives you about 2 weeks to work on. And then of course you have a quiz/mid-term, and a final exam. Because of COVID, the tests were all done on Canvas.

I would argue this course should be called as "Introduction to OOP and Algorithm" instead, because you always need to think of different algorithms to make your program work in labs and PAs. As someone who has nearly 0 programming background (I only took VBA 1022q before), thinking algorithms on a whim is challenging to me. It would be ideal if you can find someone to work and brainstorm together, because that's what I did to secure my PA scores.

Again, as someone who has very little programing background (I am a SBM student), the concept of recursion overwhelmed me a bit when I first learned about it, but later picked it up with the help of friendship. Surprisingly, I don't find pointer really hard, it is just confusing sometimes when you assign a lot of pointers, such as a binary tree structure, so make sure you have a crystal clear flow of thinking.

For the final, make sure you do past papers, review your past Labs and PAs, and remember how each algorithm in those questions work, because they can be very useful. However, as the exam was done on Canvas, you cannot use tab on the text editor, and for this semester, we were required to leave comments on our code, which could be very time-consuming, and causing many of us cannot finish the exam.

reviews.author: operator=
reviews.comment_content:
Basic C++ syntax: input/output,if else,while,for,switch,++,logic...
Function: function header,recursion,overload,default argument,header file and separate compiling...
pointer: various kinds of pointers and some algorithm like tree,linked list...
class: how to construct a class and its member function,stack and queue
reviews.comment_teaching: Since he has accent as he is from Greek(I guess),when I first attend his class, I nearly couldn't understand what he was saying.Though as the time went on I was getting used to it,there was still sometime you couldn't figure out what he was trying to say.He mainly follows the content of ppt and he will use VScode to show the examples on ppt.What differs from other instructors most is that he will give pollings nearly every lessons(it is just a practice,not an assessment),it helps us to have a better understanding of what you have learned by reading through code.
reviews.comment_grading: This term the grading is quite good.I got an overall of 79 and got A-(For last fall,this mark can only attain B+,but the mean and sd of final in this two sememsters are nearly the same).
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is much heavier than COMP1021.There are 10 labs where they is no step-by-step teaching at all.And for 3 programming assignment,it is quite time consuming especially for the third one which needs pointer and recursion.And when approaching final,it is also wise to do some past paper since most of the questions in the final requires you to complement functions,but the questions in past paper are also disgusting.

reviews.author: momobo
reviews.title: for mediocre SBM students with interest in programming!
reviews.comment_content:
you will learn much more than most IS major required courses (am not an IS student either) just getting a clearer mind/solid training in programming
basic C++ content:
(if you took java then no biggy for the beginning part)
-PBR/PBV
-function
-array, string
-separate compilation, file I/O
-struct

(the below content gets more challenging)
-recursion
-pointer
-class

-binary tree structure
-stack & queue
reviews.comment_teaching: Cindy teaches slowly and patiently as she explains everything in detail with flow charts sketched during courses. She is also more than willing to answer questions after class(she once stayed nearly 2hrs behind) or through emails. You may feel the pace is slow in the beginning but as time goes by the content also becomes trickier then you start panicking. May be way too slow for genius coders.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz: 18/24 (mean: 18.24)
Lab: full marks (3 points* 10 labs)
PA1: 100/100 (mean: 79.63)
PA2: 97.3/100 (mean: 86.87)
PA3: 96/100 (mean: 68.71)
Final: 36.5 (mean: 40.28; SD: 21.32; max : 92.5)

Letter Grade: B
Definitely need a few friends to back up you/kindly assist you along the freaking PA writing journey. I tried so hard to debug and poured blood, sweat and tears to complete all tasks. I learned so much and actually enjoyed the process nevertheless.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. The labs weren't too demanding but it comes every week so be sure to manage your time wisely.

2. As for PAs, approximately 1 day for problem reading/understanding, and coming up with some brief ideas of solution in your mind.  Actual implementation takes roughly 2-4 days, debugging is usually the most painful part(crying internally). Do start early so you will have time for revision. We had a lot of recursion problems this semester and "thinking recursively" is the key to tackle the problem.

3. Final: Though I got a shitty grade but I really did try HARD for exam prep...remember to finish all the past papers and be familiar with all the ppt contents! Just try to fully understand how all the concepts work and remember it, I mean by being able to type the whole structure down from scratch. You may cry yourself to sleep after the final since it's way too damn hard but you'll be fine if you tried hard enough, trust me.

4. General advice: First, practice typing all the coding examples on the ppts by yourself, merely understanding is far from enough. Second, when you feel like dying and really cannot compose shit then just go to Piazza to ask for help or ask that kind friend of yours to give you some feedback/support. Just never give up and believe you can surely do this, you can definitely defeat COMP2011. Good luck!!

reviews.comment_content:
C++ things
some intro of programming

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: THE introductory CS course.
reviews.comment_content: Most of the syllabus is the same as 102x, except they are taught in C++. In addition, you will learn some basic data structures and OOP.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sometimes I attended Cindy's course and sometimes I attended Cecia's. Their teaching is great as they would go through all the details by real-time coding, which makes the material clear and easy to understand.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not so good due to the fact that in Fall you need to attend the course with a lot of CS guys. I got full mark in labs, assignments; 22/25 (mean: 18) in quiz and 45 in Final (mean: 40), got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: Actually, the workload is not that high. The labs and assignments are not hard. You can definitely make it through even if you have not learned the material before. Each PA costs you about 2-3 hours to complete most of the functions. However, if you want A range, you should pay more efforts and go through as much past papers as you can. I didn't do past papers or any additional coding problems, so I got a bad grade.

reviews.author: L.K.
reviews.title: Good Lecture note + Good Instructors = Good Course
reviews.comment_content:
See attached â€œLecture Notes.pngâ€
Or you may go to the course website:
https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

â–½ Details

Part 1: Basics and Controls
Part 2: Function (Introduction)
Part 3: Array
Part 4: Recursion

Part 5: Scope
Part 6: Function III:
  - Function declaration
  - Function overloading
  - Default Function Argument

Part 7: Separate Compilation
Part 8: C++ Structure

Part 9: Pointers (Intro)
  - lvalue & rvalue
  - dereference a pointer
  - "const" in pointers initialization
  - Array as (constant) pointers

Part 10: Pointers (Usage)
  - Dynamic allocations (on Heap)
  - Problems on dynamic objects:
     ! Dangling pointer
     ! Memory leak
  - Linked List (LL)
  - LL + Binary Tree
  - Dynamic 1D and 2D array

Part 11: C++ Class (Intro)
  - Class == Struct with its own functions
  - keywords "public" and "private"
  - Constructors
     Trigger when a new object is created
  - Destructor
     Need when the object has pointers
  - Accessor
     Always followed by "const"
     Should NOT modify its data members
  - Mutator
     Opposite to accessors
  - Scope operator
     Syntax: <class_name>::
     Use to separate global function and
     member functions (Class scope)

Part 12: Stack and Queue
  - Stack: Last In First Out (LIFO)
  - Queue: First In First Out (FIFO)
  - Stack & Queue + Class
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

reviews.comment_grading:
â–½ Grading scheme
(Retrieved from the course website)

Labs - 10%
  10 Labs in total. So 1% for each lab

Programming Assignments (PAs) - 37%
  PA1: 10% (Focus: Basics and Control)
  PA2: 12% (Focus: 2D Array + Recursion)
  PA3: 15% (Focus: Recursion + Pointer)

Quiz - 8% (Focus: Basics and Control)

Final Exam - 45%
Separated into three parts
Each Part gives 45 minutes.
[Details are retrieved from canvas]

Part 1:
  Dynamic Memory (9 points)
  Recursion and Binary Tree (24 points)

Part 2:
  Function and Control Flow (9 points) *
  Class and Stack (26 points)

Part 3:
  PBV, PBR, RBR (6 points)
  Singly Linked List (7 points)
  Doubly-Linked List (19 points)

* With recursion
  So many recursion in this FINAL :(

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy
if your programming experience only
comes from course COMP1021 / 1022q.

---- 1. Lab ----

Some Labs are NOT easy.
(Especially for Lab 7 - 10)

Do recommend leaving at least one day
to finish the tasks in the lab.

---- 2. Programming Assignment ----

Tip 1:
Check the Assignment page regularly
to see if there are any updates.

Tip 2:
Always go to Piazza and ask
if you need more clarifications!

Tip 3:
Leave at least three days
to finish all the tasks in the assignment.

reviews.author: Lch20001201
reviews.title: Brian is good but somehow annoying
reviews.comment_content: Typical programming things. Arrays,pointers, recursions and some data structures(stack, queue).Please refer to what others say
reviews.comment_teaching: Brian explains a lot on the concepts but eventually not my cup of tea as it is a little annoying to me. Therefore, I literally skipped all lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
PA1:99/100
PA2:100/100
PA3:88/100
Lab: 10/10
Quiz:14/24(mean: 18.64/24)
Final:40.5/100(mean: 39.82)

Grade:B-

It is good to me somehow since i do not pay lots of effort.
reviews.comment_workload: It is not too high but if you want good grades, consider reading more past papers and self test on course websites as the quiz and exam could be very tricky. For the pa, see if you can find someone to discuss as i would be easier sometimes.

reviews.author: gerardway
reviews.title: ISOM2500
reviews.comment_content: Basic statistics stuff, if you took m1 in DSE it should be very easy for you. But I donâ€™t have that background so struggled a bit
reviews.comment_teaching: It was difficult, YouTube videos teach better the concepts. YouTube videos can teach the concepts much faster than in a lecture
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. If you practice a lot you can get a ok grade, it is something you can do better especially when you can find past papers online, helps a lot
reviews.comment_workload: Reasonable workload, again just the practicing takes time but coursework wise it is fine

reviews.author: urwlcmt
reviews.title: Great Teaching, Challenging yer Manageable Workload
reviews.comment_content: Covers the basics of C++, i.e. data types, syntax, logic, flow control, array, function, struct, pointer and some introductory OOP concepts. Later topics may be quite challenging for students with few programming background.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great teaching from lecturer: clear explanations, good pace, and timely help if needed.
TA could have been better,
reviews.comment_grading: Will get all marks in assignments and labs if you do everything you're asked to, which are manageable with enough time and effort.
reviews.comment_workload: Three assignments throughout the semester; later ones were relatively challenging, but not impossible if you spend enough time. Exam is quite challenging, require quick thinking.

reviews.author: LIWENBO
reviews.comment_content:
1-5: intro, basic and logic control (self study, only examples will be covered on lecture)
6: function
7: array
8: recursion
9. scope
10: struct
11: function prototype and overloading
12: separate compilation
13: pointer (very long and important chapter with many content)
14: class
15: stack

If you took the python course, there will be a lot of new concepts to learn as python is too easy to use. It is better for Java.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof MAK was very helpful and try to answer almost every questions (sometimes may spend too much time answering questions). The pace is a little slow but it is ok for most students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment 1: 10%
Assignment 2: 12%
Assignment 3: 14%
Quiz: 8%
Lab work: 10%
Final exam: 46%

Assignment 1: 100/100 mean 88.2
Assignment 2: 92/100 mean 78.8
Assignment 3: 88/100 mean 82.1
Quiz: 22/24 mean 18.6
Lab: full mark (each lab has 3 points, completing the lab tasks will earn 3 points while attending the lab but fail to complete the task will only earn 1 mark)
Final: 77/100 mean 39.8
Got A at last
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is terribly large. There are 3 programming assignments and all of these require several days to finish and are hard to debug. It is better to complete the lab tasks in advance because at the beginning of the lab session the TA will ask students to demo in break out room by random order. Some lab tasks are quite time comsuming so it's like a weekly homework. Sometimes the prof may ask for additional classes because they cannot cover so much materials in the normal class time. For the final exams, it is better to reserve enough time to go over all the course materials and do some past paper to practice as it can be terribly hard and may cover a lot of details.

reviews.author: hugolth
reviews.comment_content:
This course teach the basic of C++. Including
1.Some basic syntax of C++ like variable declaration,operators, different kinds of loop
2.String and recursions
3.Pointer,call by value and call by reference
4.Simple data structure like linked list, 1d array and 2d array
  The content is good as a beginner of C++ programming, but if you have the knowledge from other languages then you just have to learn the syntax and the special feature of C++.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof.Chan teach well during lecture. Her voice is clear and her English is good. Although she follow most of the content from powerpoint, there are some extra demonstration and reminder during lectures. Also she is willing to reply email in English.
  For the tutors in labs, the tutor in my session is easy going and will not be too restructive towards the labs. But as this year is online learning. The order of demonstration in labs is random. So there was one time I have to wait two hour for the demo.
  For the exam, I think the rules for testing in online was too harsh, there are too much requirement compare with other subject.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are four parts count for the grade:
1. 3 assignments
2. 9 labs
3. Short Quiz
4. Final exam
  Since online learning, the mean of assignment and lab is high(>90%). The labs will provide clear guidance and not difficult. But the assignment is hard and have to carefully. Even you pass the new zinc automatic grading system,your program may not pass some exetreme cases not shown. For the quiz, it only contains MC so it is easy. But final is hard and required writing functional code without code editor.

My grade:
Labs : full marks
Quiz:21/24(mean:19)
Assignment: 99 85 80 (mean:89 79 82)
Final:40(mean:39.8)
Grade:B-
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not heavy when beginning, but heavier when near finals. Since the concepts behinds is getting more difficult and the homework become more harder. I used to study only 1-2 hours at the beginning of course, but the time doubled at later time. Also I think the exam require doing a lot of past paper such that you can familiar with the strange exam format.

reviews.author: MingHin
reviews.comment_content: C++ basic contents.
reviews.comment_teaching:
good teaching.
speaks explicitly and always encourage students to answer questions. Cindy teaches at a relatively slow speed so even one is a slow thinker, one can still understand the content. But to what degree of understanding depends on your programming sense.
reviews.comment_grading:
Bad grade for me.
There are 2 passing requirements: Overall >= some% AND (final + quiz)>= some%. I met the first requirement but due to my poor mental condition during the final exam, I failed to meet the second requirement and I got an F.
reviews.comment_workload:
very heavy workload.
3 very long and demanding programming assignments throughout the semester.
a lab for every week (smaller assignments but still time-consuming).

reviews.author: Trin
reviews.title: If you are ~Mean, then you are C+... If you are not (super) passionate about programming, you may give this a miss.
reviews.comment_content:
Nearly all the C++ Basic, but some important but harder ones are left to COMP2012.

The coverage of topics:
Topics:
1.  C++ Basics
2. Control Flow
3. Basics 2
4. Control 2
5. Function 1
6. Array
7. Function 2 Recursion
8. Scope
9. Struct
10. Function 3 Miscellaneous
11. Separate Compilation
12. Pointer
13. C++ Class
14. Stack and Queue

Intended learning outcomes:
1. Use common software tools to develop and debug a program written in an OOP language. : Use an IDE such as VS Code proficiently to write, compile, run, and debug a C++ program consisting of one or many source files.
2. Write a short program to solve a simple problem in an OOP language.: Construct a solution to a written problem by writing a complete C++ program of no more than 500 lines of codes on one's own. !without the requirements are clearly explained and the required programming constructs are told!
3. Demonstrate that recursive and non-recursive functions are abstractions of sub-problems in a task.: Demonstrate thorough understanding of how recursion works. Be able to develop a recursive solution to a written problem on one's own, and sometimes contrast it with the corresponding non-recursive solution.
4. Describe the concept and the use of pointers in indirect addressing and dynamic memory allocation.: Demonstrate strong understanding of the concept of pointers. Is able to use pointers effectively in indirect addressing and dynamic memory allocation in a great variety of scenarios.
5. Demonstrate the use of several data structures.:Is able to choose the appropriate data structures such as linked lists, stacks and queues to solve problems, and implement the solution in C++ on one's own.
6. Implement an abstract data type by defining a class in an OOP language.: Given the description of a simple ADT, is able to implement it with a complete C++ class definition that includes appropriate class members and class member functions. Is able to write programs that create and manipulate ADT objects. (ADT: abstract data type)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia is a very approachable teacher who is always willing to listen to and respond to students' needs. The pace of the lectures can be quickened up during the first half while it would be better to slow down during the latter half of the lectures. (on   topics like recursion, Pointer and linked nodes)

TAs are very approachable and considerate too. I gained lots of help from them. Thanks TAs!
reviews.comment_grading:
* Many C+ in C++ is true! *

If you happen to get a mean, unfortunately many C+ in C++ class... You will probably score a C+... That is unlike to the school business school norm. Usually if you are close to/ at mean, then you can gain a B-/ B. But it seems this is another story for engineering course...

However, with a class size of 400, there was quite a number of genius students who did not only did pretty good job on nailing the course but also helped the other students on piazza.
I really appreciate them! I can see the tech talents are really rising... Thanks all who helped me on the learning journey despite the online mode.
reviews.comment_workload:
*Super heavy but worthy if you are pursuing a software engineering career*

From the perspective of a business student, the workload is super heavy... As a 4 credit course, it should be heavy, but the actual amount of work is even beyond that... Every week, apart from lecture hours, it is the best to spare 7-8 hours to revise and finish the labs. For the assignments, it is the best to spare 24 hours (accumulated) for each one if you aim to finish them near perfection. I counted my hours that I spent on this course, the hour was crazy (maybe it is because I don't really adapt to the mode of a programmer which is aka sitting in front of the computer for an afternoon/ a whole day straight every weekend.)

reviews.author: below_mean_guy
reviews.comment_content:
Main topics are:

- Basics and Controls
- Functions
- Arrays
- Recursion
- Scope
- Struct
- Separate Compilation
- Pointer
- Class
- Stack & Queue

The basics and controls (which are similar to those covered in the prerequisite courses) are covered in the first two weeks.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is adequate to medium level students. Cecia teaches quite slow and explains everything very clearly.

Besides, my lab TA (Wallace) is very good. His teaching has some fun in it and he can answer your question very quickly and clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair.

The grading scheme is as follows:
Lab - 10%
Assignments - 36% (10+12+14)
Quiz - 8%
Final - 46%

If you aim for a pass, you have to get a separate pass in exams and assignments (the passing mark fluctuates, but guaranteed to be not more than 50% of lab + assignments and not more than 30% of quiz + final)

Stats for this sem (according to Canvas):
Labs: 9.XX/10
Assignments: 82.2%,78.8%,82.1%
Quiz: 18.6/24
Final: 39.8/100
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite high, but it is suitable for a 4-credit course.

The assignments can take you a lot of time as they are somehow very challenging.

Some labs are easy, but some can also take you some time. You have to try the labs before your lab session.

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Have fun fighting cheaters
reviews.comment_content:
Basic C++ content:
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue
File input / output (not in exam)

Necessary for CS/CPEG students, and therefore as a CPEG student it was useful and I would say that it is quite interesting if you are interested in programming. If you are a year 1 student I would not suggest this course however unless you already know C++ well or VERY confident in your abilities.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rated at B, but is more of a B-.

It is commendable that Cecia does try to make the lectures interesting with some live coding sections, but in the end she ends up mostly repeating what is written on the lecture powerpoints.

Speaking of the powerpoints, they were only acceptable for learning the most basic of the concepts, if you think these can help you do the labs or the assignments, you would be wrong. Spend time learning on Youtube/Google instead. Lectures were not mandatory so its up to you if you want to attend.

Labs were OK, wait for your turn to demonstrate the code and you are done, was arranged a bit messily at first but got OK later. You could demo the code before it is your turn if you just join the Zoom meeting before the lab session.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lab: 10%
Programming assignments 1: 10%
Programming assignments 2: 12%
Programming assignments 3: 16%
Quiz: 8%
Final exam: 46%

Lab: 1 per week, finish a program related to the course content that week, not to difficult to get full marks since the programs are not too complex, and you can always "ask" for help.

Quiz: Taken on a month into the semester, short refresher for things like if-else, loops and such. Averages were high. (mean: 18/24)

Programming Assignments: 3 in total, each were on a different area (recursion, pointers and such), challenging, takes a few days, however, cheating was rampant with the assignments, so averages for them were absurdly high and the department has done nothing to combat people buying code off of others, so prepared to lose a few percent of the final score if you either have integrity or are not highly skilled in C++.

Finals: 45 minute sessions, 3 sessions in total, all short questions based on reading code/writing code, this meant studying the notes were almost completely useless. This also means that if you have spent time writing code you would probably do slightly better. The exam was also formatted poorly, meaning you have to scroll up and down just to even read the question, and you have to type code in the CANVAS message box, which gives you no option to use tab to space out your code, and no other formatting options.

However none of these really mattered since the final was outrageously difficult. You are expected to finish 2 programs (about 8 functions in total) in about 35 minutes, which is absurd, mean at the end was about 40/100.

My grades:
Labs: full mark
Assignments: 9/10%, 9.5/12%, 16/16%
Quiz: 20/24
Finals: 45/100

Over all rounds up to about mean or so, and got a B, instead of a B- that I was expected, therefore grading is good in my opinion.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy.

Each lab takes a few hours to complete, especially the later ones as the later labs requires you to finish 4-5 different functions, and the difficulty gap between the lecture notes and the labs/assignments is huge, so you need to spend time learning everything yourself. Assignments usually take a few days to complete, if you are really stuck there could be a chance that someone on the piazza (discussion forum for the course) will help you.

However at the same time because you need to do so much studying just to finish the lab and assignments, if you actually did everything yourself (Hard to say for people in this course!), you would have a decent idea of everything, especially for writing code which is VERY important for the final as I have explained.

reviews.author: Miracles
reviews.title: Truely hope that you don't need to take the exam on Canvas
reviews.comment_content:
C++ stuffs
Not that difficult to students who had program before.
For those who never program before, you better focus on every boring lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Profs:
I saw that he really love and will to pay effort in teaching. There are many strange questions in the chatroom and he give us clear explanations to all the questions. However, teaching programming stuffs must be boring. Do not expect that you will have so much fun in the lecture.

Tutor:
I was taught by Wallace for the tutorials. Most of the time in the tutorials will be used to check your homework. But there will be around 10 mins teaching session before checking. For the teaching part, he always put some meme in his powerpoint and make the tutorial less boring. For the checking part, I had made a mistake in my program once. He can point it out and let me understand what's is wrong in a short period of time. So, I think his teaching skill is quite good too.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not yet release.

Marks gain from:
1.Exam
2.Assignment
3.Tutorial
4.Quiz

For 2 and 3, it is not difficult to get all the marks.
For 4, it's a normal quiz.

For 1, it's a disaster to us.
In this semester, we take the exam on Canvas. The profs says that it should be more easier as we can type using keyboard. BUT, it just a joke.

For the short question, we just need to read the code and write the output. It's ok if it's not some long code.

For the long question, it's insane. The question is like a long eassy pasted on the Canvas. The question is listed at the top and the answer box is listed at the bottom. You will need to scroll downward  at least 2 - 3 times (using your mouse wheel) to reach the answer box. The question ask you to fill your answer in the blank. But, actually you need to copy the whole things from the question to your answer box. However, the question is not a text that you can copy, but an image. So, you need to scroll up 3 times, remember it, scroll down 3 times, write it, fill in your answer, scroll up 3 times, check it again, scroll down 3 times, check it again. Then you finish the part a) (i). That mean you need to repeat it for many many many time to answer a single long question.

It seems that it is not my personal problem as the mean is really low even though the question is not that difficult.

For the Exam, the mean is 39.8.
For the Assignments, the mean is always around 8x% while there are always >200 students in my lecture group get full marks.

So, I truely hope that you don't need to take the exam on Canvas.
reviews.comment_workload:
You will need to do your homework every week. If you are good at programming, you may only need about 2 - 3 hours to finish it. Otherwise, you may need to spend a whole day to complete it.

It's quite a suffer because the profs will release a new homework after you finished checking the current homework.

Unlimited HomeWork.

reviews.author: yaboi
reviews.title: You will learn C++ but your grades won't reflect it
reviews.comment_content:
1. Intro
2. Basics 1, 2; Control 1, 2:
Basic syntax of C++, program control.
3. Function I:
Function definition, modular programming, passing parameter (PBV and PBR)
4. Array:
1d, 2d, higher dimension arrays, array definition, initialisation, C string (special type of char[])
5. Recursion:
6. Scope
7. Struct
8. Function III
9. Separate-Compilation
10. Pointer
11. Class
12. Stack and Queue

Honestly, everything upto Pointer is pretty easy stuff. Might be my bias since I studied some basic C++ in COMP1029C and by myself over the summer. The content progression is pretty good but I won't lie, you are better off watching one of those 3-4 hour long C++ tutorials over the span of a week or two and you'll learn (almost) everything in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Brian is a decent teacher. He obviously knows what he's teaching very well and will give you the lower level explanation of most C++ functionality if you ask for it.

The lectures are paced quite poorly in my opinion though. I dont know whether to blame him or whoever made this course syllabus but it spends way to long on basic stuff and too little time on complex topics.

I recommend you self-study most of this course because of this awkward pacing. However, if you have never seen C/C++ code then attending a few lectures might be worthwhile.
reviews.comment_grading:
Ok, so my grade isn't out yet but I will edit my review once it is.

To pass this course, it is not sufficient to have your total score greater than or equal to the pass mark. You are also required to obtain a separate pass mark in your exams. That is, to pass, you are required to have
(total score >= X) AND (quiz score * 0.08 + final exam score * 0.46 >= Y).
X and Y will be determined at the end of the semester but we may promise you that:
X will not be greater than 50, and
Y will not be greater than 16.
(It is assumed that all scores in the above formula are scaled to 100 maximum.)

lab exercises:                      10%
programming assignments: 36% (10%, 12%, 14%)
quiz:                               8%
final exam:                           46%

Means:
Labs: around 2.8/3
PAs: 88.2%, 78.8%, 84.9% (acc. to Canvas)
these means were way higher than previous sems but the assignments were quite easy so I understand why.
Quiz: 79.2%
Final: 40%

Me:
Labs, PAs: 100%
Quiz: 79%
Final: 63.5%
Edit: This got me an A.
Little rant: the final was one of the most poorly designed assessment of a student's skills I have ever seen. Maybe I am just a butthurt baby but seriously, this typing code on Canvas (without being able to use Tabs or a separate text editor) is so time consuming. Plus, you have to remember all variable/class/function names otherwise you spend half your time scrolling back and forth from the code in the question and your code box. Many of the questions basically required you to write an algorithm to perform certain actions like shifting all the elements in a 2D array (without any indexing, only pointers) but you have to dry run everything in your head. Like when and where do you ever have to dry run such a complex algorithm in the real world?!??! A programming course shouldn't even have a final exam, but rather, have really hard projects instead.
reviews.comment_workload: Again, I basically knew C++ coming into this course so the weekly labs and the programming assignments were quite easy. The labs maybe took 2 hours at most, usually an hour though. The assignments took a lot longer though. People complained about memory leaks or whatever but they really aren't that big of an issue in my opinion. Use Zinc to test all your submissions and you'll probably get full too. Overall, appropriate for a 4 cr course.

reviews.author: å‡æª¸èŒ¶ (æœªå‡)
reviews.title: The course was easy BUT ONLINE EXAM WAS HARD
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture notes are pretty clear.
The whole course was challenging but somehow in an adequate level.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Brian's teaching was very clear, in a good pace, including a lot of details. I really like it :)

*Even if you don't like his teaching style, its okay to skip them :P
reviews.comment_grading:
Most students taking this course are EXPERTS in programming!~
assignments and quiz means are always high, so never expect to get an easy A from this course.
Understanding all the course materials was easy, but in quiz and exam they always expect you to code and compile the programs in your mind like your computer...Especially in online exam, it was nearly impossible to finish all questions within the limited time. Good luck! :)
reviews.comment_workload:
labs and assignments are usually easy, but they might take days for beginners to google and learn to do them.

pretty much the easiest 4 credit course in cs :)

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: The first course in C++
reviews.comment_content:
1. Intro
2. Basics1, 2; Control 1, 2:
Basic syntax of C++, program control.
----Quiz----
3. Function I:
Function definition, modular programming, passing parameter (PBV and PBR)
4. Array:
1d, 2d, higher dimension arrays, array definition, initialisation, C string (special type of char[])
5. Recursion**:
The hardest topic involving logical thinking
6. Scope
7. Struct
8. Function III
9. Separate-Compilation:
Actually you have to know its application, but the code will not be examined.
10. Pointer**:
The hardest topic involving very clear concepts. lvalue and rvalue, pointers, linked list**, dynamic arrays**, memory leaks**
11. Class:
data-member, member functions, constructors and destructor, mutators and accessors
12. Stack and Queue:
Only Stack is examined this year.

I will say not all topics are new to people who can get into this course. Most of them are just different by syntax. Therefore, please do read every slide of your lecture notes. They are pretty short actually. Do recall everything covered in the quiz as they will ask you tricky questions (like those in COMP1022P). The final exam will focus more on writing codes instead of tricky questions, which is what a COMP course suppose to be :)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia is very good at explaining concepts and she has good English with intonations :)

Sometimes she will make some silly mistakes, but that doesn't affect too much.

She will provide more details about labs and PAs during lessons, it will be great if you do it after watching her videos. (In this semester, we can assess all the lecture videos of the 4 sessions)

Btw, there is a piazza for everyone to post questions and everyone can reply. Better check out some questions when you got stuck in PA as many generous students are giving tips :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 8%
Lab 10%
PA 36% (10, 12 14%)
Final 46%

The quiz will examine the basic of C++. Therefore if you take 1021 before, please do more revision.

For the final exam, there are 3 parts and each part last for 45 minutes. You have to code in the Canvas textbox which TAB CANNOT BE USED and YOU HAVE TO SCROLL UP AND DOWN to copy the function prototypes :) (They banned copying)

There consists of at least one coding problem in each part and you have to understand the LONG PASSAGE and write codes. I think they do all these INTENTIONALLY to limit our time. Three tips for people taking this kind of exam later:
1. Write your code in recursive ways (usually iterative way cost more time)
2. Be sure that you can write all function taught in class without much thinking...they examine some functions like deleting linked list which already stated in the lecture notes :)
3. Mark down those important things (like prototypes, data structures...), so that you don't have to scroll up and down :D

Grade and Marks are not released...many students get ANNIHILATED by this exam ;)

----Update----
Assignment: Full
Lab: 8/9 (missing 1 lab)
Quiz: Full
Final: 78/100
Overall marks ~ 88/100
Final grade: A+

Actually I do surprised by the final grade. Since the highest of the final exam is around 92 and I am quite far from it. Better than what I expected :D
reviews.comment_workload:
No attendance for class.
1 lab every week, 3 Programming assignments, 1 quiz, 1 final

We have to finish the lab before and demo during lab session. Therefore, you have to finish it quickly and no TA can help you :( (at least for my session)

The difficulty of PA2 will be the highest since it examines the implementation of the hardest logical-demanding topic --> recursion. I know some students takes weeks to finish it. For me it takes around 20-25 hours in total.
The other 2 PA are easier, finish within 1 day.

Workload really depends on your own experience and expectations.

If you take 1021/1022q as the prerequisite, then please pay more attention because C++ is completely different from python and VBA. Especially 1021 teaches turtle??? which is useless in this course...
I think the most difficult things for 1021 students will be the syntax and concepts of OOP. (As python is too easy to use!)

If you take 1022p as the prerequisite, congrats! Those content taught in 1022p are useful in 2011(because it is also OOP). Some topics like "Class" will be easy for you :)

reviews.author: Andy Leung
reviews.title: Easy to study, hard to get high grade
reviews.comment_content: This course teaches basic concepts of C++, such as pointers, simple data types, and classes. The materials taught are very useful in comp2012, which I considered as a sequel of 2011. If you are very interested in c++, I recommend you to reg COMP2012H instead of (COMP2011 + COMP2012)
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia is a nice person. She wouldn't mind spending a lot of time answering your questions. Also, the way she taught was not boring at all.
reviews.comment_grading:
Due to online lecturing, the grading system is different from other semesters.
10% - Lab Exercises + Attandance
44% - Programming assignment
(8% - pa1, 10% - pa2, 14% - pa3, 12% - pa4)
1% - Final exam dry-run in the last lab session
45% - Final

For me, I get an A- with
100/100 - lab
70/100 - pa1
84/100 - pa2
72/100 - pa3
100/100 - pa4
1/1 - Final exam dry-run
85.5/100 - final
reviews.comment_workload: Each week(except midterm and final week) has a lab assignment to do. Other than that, there were 4 programming assignments to do throughout the course. For me, the assignments are somewhat tricky, and easy to lose points due to unexpected reasons. If you want to get 100% for your assignments, the workload is very heavy. Other than that, the workload overall is similar to other COMP courses.

reviews.author: Qin
reviews.title: heavy hell workload
reviews.comment_content: li xin is really a nice teacher and she will respond to your inquiry email as soon as possible
reviews.comment_teaching:
3hr lecture per week
may be expecting some additional class at the end of the semester
2hr lab session per week
you need to write the code before class and then demo it to the teaching assistant. the teaching assistant maybe roasted you with some questions but generally, he/she is nice
reviews.comment_grading: there are tons of talented students and they have already learned this topic in highschool.. so you really need to start earlier and work harder to get above mean.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 programming assignments. 8-20hr/assignment (as the teacher suggested)
and maybe 5hr for each lab per week.

anyway, the workload is fair for 4 credit courses.

reviews.author: JeffreyChau
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction
C++ Basics/Control
Function
Array
Recursion
Scope
Structure
Separate Compilation
Pointers & Dynamic Data
C++ Class
