Good content, clear notes and examples.
Interesting assignment (topic related to real life)
reviews.comment_teaching:
- good teaching speed
- clear explanation
- disable chat function in Zoom
- can ask questions using mic
- with interaction using the Zoom function (Yes/No)
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading -
Assignment all full
Lab full
Final exam 84/100
A+

Good grade because even I have many careless mistakes in exam I can still get A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Lab each week with low workload

4 assignments -
First two low workload (easy)
Last two (pointer, class) higher workload (harder)

reviews.author: NaturalEthan
reviews.title: The syllabus can be improved!
reviews.comment_content:
Very Basic knowledge about C ++
Course webpage:
https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011/web/lectureNotes.html

Syllabus
C++ Basics
Control Flow
Basics II
Control II
Problems for Basics and Control
Function I
Array
Function II: Recursion
Function III: Miscellaneous
Scope
Struct
Separate Compilation
File I/O
Pointer
C++ Class
Stack & Queue ( self study in this semester)
New C++ Features( self study in this semester)
C++ String( self study in this semester)


The content is very basic for beginners. However, the time arrangement is very inappropriate. Some basic features like control flow, array, recursion, etc. have been covered in COMP1022P, COMP1022Q, but they occupied half of the semester's time. However, very important and difficult parts like Pointers and Classes were taught in a short time even if 2 PAs need to applicate them and more than 50% percent credits of the final exam are related to them.
  So what I want to remind you is that if you have time, try to self study this course as fast as you can so then you have more time to deal with Class and Pointer.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia teaches in a very friendly and interactively way. Her teaching is very clear and vivid. However, if you are confident enough, you can just study by yourself because the slides are elaborated very well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Below is the grading scheme.

lab exercises                                             10%
mean is close to full mark

programming assignments                         44%
PA1                                                                  8%
mean = 77.18, STD = 31.22
PA2                                                                  10%
mean = 84.4, STD = 25.9
PA3                                                                  14%
mean = 68.3, STD = 33.0
PA4                                                                  12%
mean = 60.3, STD = 45.1

final exam dry-run in the last lab session 1%
final exam                                                 45%
mean = 52.97; STD = 22.19

TOTAL                                                             100%

No bonus this semester.

Because there is no midterm exam in this semester, PA3 and PA4 are very challenging.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is a little bit high. Because PA3 and PA4 cost lots of time. I remember I spent more than 20 hours to finish and debug PA3, more than 5 hours to debug PA4. PA3 and PA4 are challenging and hassle. You need to write 300 to 500 lines code to finish your task: analyze dozens of KB data and print dozens of KB result.

reviews.author: holam
reviews.title: COMP 2011
reviews.comment_content:
DO NOT take this course if this is not your required course. I know there are some subjects with COMP 2011 as electives. For Example:
QSA: methodology elective, please take other courses like SOSC and MARK, your life will be easier
QFIN: area B elective, please take ISOM 3360 and 3370 instead, with much lower difficulty (I guess you donâ€™t want to make your GPA down)
ENGG, SCIE, etc.

This course is good for a programmer, but useless except this.

Btw, if you got an A+ in COMP 1021, you can still get a C+ in COMP 2011

All in all, avoid this if you can.
reviews.comment_teaching: Desmond > Cecia> others> mak brian
reviews.comment_grading: Bad grade: Fall sem you will study with CS and DSCT guys, mean is crazy, Spring sem you will see lower mean, but then the grade will surprise you(a lot of C+ in C++!)
reviews.comment_workload: Huge workload: 3 assignments with wasting you much time

reviews.author: Sfvpcwl
reviews.title: REALLY need study hard...
reviews.comment_content:
C++ basics
Control Flow
Function
.Array
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Separate compilation
Pointer
C++ Class
Stack and Queue
reviews.comment_teaching: Cindy put a lot of effort in teaching, it might be too slow but I think it is never too bad to ensure student understand the course content.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was based on assignments, labs, and the final exam. There was no midterm exam.

It is hard to get A range but relatively easy to secure C and above, all in all, everyone is pursuing CS......
reviews.comment_workload: Horrible weekly lab exercise and 4 PA. PA3, which about pointer, should be the nightmare of many student(like me...)

reviews.author: Yash
reviews.comment_content: The content of the course was really interesting. It will teach you the basics of c++ really well. From variables to classes and objects, the content gets interesting as the course proceeds.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture slides are detailed and very self-explanatory. They have examples for each and every concept. The code files for each example are also uploaded on the course website for assistance.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was based on assignments, labs, and the final exam. There was no midterm exam. It was replaced by an assignment. The grading is very reasonable. All appeals are catered to and inspected carefully. If marks are reduced, the reasons are given specifically. However, the course was really competitive. The online version of the final exam was graded appropriately and marks were given for steps and not just the final code.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is more than the other courses. Every week, there is a lob where you have to demonstrate the code for the task for that given lab. If you fail to do so properly, marks are deducted. So you have to be prepared before the lab each week.

The assignments consume a lot of time as well. A couple assignments took weeks to finish. There were four assignments. The third one was the hardest.

Additionally, the course content has a lot to learn. Therefore. keeping up with the lectures is important.

reviews.author: ä¸Šæµ·ç˜é¾è™Žé¬¥
reviews.title: tough course
reviews.comment_content:
1. C++ basics
2. Control Flow
3. Basics II (Loop, if statement etc)
4. Function
5. Array
6. Recursion
7. Scope
8. Struct
9. Separate compilation
10. File I/O (extra)
11. Pointer
12. C++ Class
13. Stack and Queue
14. New C++ 11 features (extra)
15. C++ strings (extra)

For extra topics, they will not be covered in final exam, but they may appear in your lab and PAs.

Since comp1021/1022P/1022Q is pre-requisite, you should find it easy to follow the basics such as loop and if statement, however it will be more difficult when it comes to recursion and pointer. Class is quite straight forward after you study pointer. Pay more attention to recursion and pointer since they will be mainly focused in your final exam:)
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia teaches with a suitable pace. Her English is clear and good. She is also very nice and if you have any questions, you can ask them during lecture. Besides, she does not just read the lecture notes, but she demonstrates some programs of the corresponding topic to consolidate the knowledge taught in the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is extremely good in this semester, probably due to online semester.
Grading scheme is as following.

Lab exercises 10%
programming assignments 44% (8%, 10%, 14%, 12%)
final exam dry-run in the last lab session 1%
final exam 45%

Mean:
Lab overall: 87.5
Final Exam Dry-run: 0.9
PA1: 77.18 SD: 31.22
PA2: 84.4 SD: 25.9
PA3: 68.3 SD: 33
PA4: 60.3 SD: 45.1
Final Exam (part 1) : 18.4
Final Exam (part 2) : 18.1
Final Exam (part 3) : 16.6
Final (total): 52.97 SD: 22.19

My score:
Lab overall: 100
Final Exam Dry-run: 1
PA1: 100
PA2: 90
PA3: 96
PA4: 100
Final Exam (part 1) : 25.5
Final Exam (part 2) : 19
Final Exam (part 3) : 28
Final (total): 72.5

Final grade: A

Friendly reminder: the grading is just suitable for online semester :)
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is heavy, but is reasonable and acceptable because it is a 4 credit course.
Lab exercise every week. For me, it usually takes me a few hours in the weekend to finish it.
4 programming assignments are in total. PA1 and PA2 is quite easy and it takes me a whole weekend to finish it. PA3 is a disaster and it takes me over one week to finish it and do memory-leak checking. PA4 is easy and it takes me a weekend to finish it.
Under normal circumstance, only 3 PAs should be given.
Treat your labs and PAs seriously since it definitely helps your understanding of the concept and logic behind. For me, since I do my lab and PAs all on my own, I do not need to revise much for the final exam.

reviews.author: hime
reviews.title: This review is written from perspective of a non-cse student who has little programming knowledge beforehand
reviews.comment_content:
DISCLAIMER: If you are mature in C++ programming before taking this course, this review is not suitable for you as you should be able to master this course easily.

I am a non-CSE student who has little programming background. I took this course for interest and you can expect there are quite a number of students who already have learnt all the content before taking this course.

For the syllabus in details, please see the other recent reviews as I believe they do not change it. Basically it covers all the basics of c++ programming, i.e., array, string, recursion, pointer, class, etc.

It is not hard in the beginning as it is quite straight forward and your should cover those ideas in COMP1XXX. Things start to become harder when it covers recursive function, and the difficulties comes to its maximum at pointer.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia is a passionate lecturer, I can feel that she always tries her best to make everything clear. However, her tone is kind of dull (maybe due to zoom lecture instead of face-to-face) so you may fall asleep in the middle. Overall she is still a good lecturer.
reviews.comment_grading:
Overall Weighting
Lab 10%
Assignment 8, 10, 14, 12%
Final Exam 44%
Trial Run of Final Exam 1%

As I applied P/F for this semester, I don't really care too much about the grading, yet you still need to get a 50% overall AND 35% (35/100) in your final exam in order to pass this course. As far as I know, this course is very competitive so if you really want to get a good grade, you have to get almost full mark in all the assignments as well as exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
In my opinion, the workload of this course is actually normal as a 4-credit course. There is a lab released in every week. However there is no plagiarism checking for labs so you can simply copy the code from your friends or even from online, yet doing it by yourself is still highly recommended.

The programming assignments(PA) is the main workload during the semester, they are significantly more complex than the labs, so you probably need more time to finish them. In general, I highly recommend to start working on it once it is released because I don't think you can use one day to finish the whole PA, especially for the later ones. The first two PAs are not that hard so most people get full marks in them. However, PA3 is really disastrous and mind-blowing, you probably need to spend a lot of time to understand the requirement even you start to code anything for it. PA4 is less difficult than PA3, but it is still hard. Generally speaking , the workload of the PAs is quite high, especially for the last two PAs, you probably need to spend a lot of time in grinding it if you really want to get full mark in all PAs.

P.S. Don't try to copy directly from others for PA, it definitely doesn't work in the way you want.

reviews.author: Tomoka
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
Introduction to computer programming
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue
File input / output

This term is taught by online Zoom meeting. There are 10 labs in total (with 1 lab session per week), and 4 assignments (which are called PAs). Pretty dense contents are covered in one single semester, I seriously recommend having a bit of programming knowledge before taking this course (such as taking COMP1021, which is the introductory programming course).
reviews.comment_teaching: Sander is a very friendly, great professor. He tries to give a lot of coding examples and explanations are clear. He is open to questions during lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
lab exercises 10%
programming assignments 44% (8%, 10%, 14%, 12%)
final exam dry-run in the last lab session 1%
final exam 45%

This course is special that you need to have separate pass mark for final exam, which is not greater than 35 points out of 100.
reviews.comment_workload: Skeleton codes are provided usually for every lab tasks and assignments. But to be honest, for a person like me who have a minimal background in programming, basically took 80% of the time doing labs and assignments (and 20% doing homework from other courses). PA3 and PA4 are quite difficult, and it takes a lot of time to do, especially PA3. Still, I think the workload is quite heavy for a 4-credit course. I wouldn't want to take this course if it was not a requirement for my major.

reviews.author: Zagala
reviews.comment_content:
Covers various basics of C++, including:
1. Basic syntax
2. Control flow
3. Functions
4. Arrays
5. Recursion
6. Scope
7. Struct
8. Pointers
9. Dynamic Data
10. Class
11. File I/O
reviews.comment_teaching: Brian is a patient lecturer who explains concepts clearly, making clarifications whenever someone has problems. His pace of teaching could be kind of slow if you are familiar with programming. Personally I am rather new to programming considering I have only taken COMP1021 at the point when I take this course, and I find his way of teaching helpful throughout my study on the course.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is relatively harsh on this course considering there is many ambitious students who is proficient on programming taking this course. You might struggle a bit on the grading if you have limited experience on it. In my semester, the final examination has been cancelled so the grading was based on Quiz for basic programming knowledge (5%) + Lab exercises (10%) + Midterm (25%) + 4 programming assignments (6% + 8% + 10% + 10% = 34%). I was at the mean for most of these assignments and screwed up the last two programming assignments (got 10/100 and 60/100 respectively as I was so unfamiliar with pointers) ending up with a C.
reviews.comment_workload: Depending on how good you are at programming, the workload could be either light or extremely high for you. For normal semesters, there will be a midterm and a final examination, 10 lab exercises and 3-4 programming assignments. Take your time to revise all those concepts taught in class if you don't want to spend a whole week just for doing one single programming assignment!

reviews.title: Difficult for beginner
reviews.comment_content: teach you the basic of c++,include variable, different loops, structure, class,dynamic memory,recursion,stack,the most difficult is POINTER.
reviews.comment_teaching: explain clear and seriously, but fall asleep easily.If you miss something, it is hard to catch up later. Lecture videos are provided.Do not skip classes.
reviews.comment_grading: I don't have java background, it is more difficult than python.  midterm below mean, final only get 20/100,then I failed the course. Quiz 5% + lab exercises 10% + programming assignments (8%x3) 24% + midterm exam 25% + final exam 36%. But passing the course is not difficult, work harder!
reviews.comment_workload: high. one week one lab, 3 assigments, midterm and final.Quiz.

reviews.comment_content:

You'd better take COMP2012H because taking COMP2011 and COMP2012 is a waste of time.

Perfect grading!
It is not difficult to get A+. if you got slightly over 95% totally, you could get A+.

BTW, the grading part is just suitable for 19-20 Fall.
reviews.comment_workload:

If you have taken COMP1021/1022P/1022Q or you have programming background, you can finish assignment quickly.

reviews.author: TomNotch
reviews.title: Fundamental
reviews.comment_content: The content of COMP 2011 is easy at the beginning, as it's the basic about data type and programme flow, would be similar to Java you learnt last semester. But do not under estimate the difficulty of dynamic memory allocation, easy understanding, also easy making mistake.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is too detailed that sometimes you're gonna feel that the professor is repeating one simple concept over and over again, which could have been taught in a few words. It's too slow.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is normal, do not under estimate the difficulty of the last few assignments, as it's about dynamic memory allocation, and passing the skeleton test code doesn't mean passing the assignment to any degree, it's easy to get memory leaked even the programme runs normally at the beginning. About exam, don't over estimate it, it's actually not that difficult, but be careful about the lambda expression.
reviews.comment_workload: The first few assignments are easy so it won't take up much time, but again the last few assignments are a bit time-consuming and difficult. About lab, it's easy, don't spent too much time on it.

reviews.author: WildHunt
reviews.title: A course which you need to work hard
reviews.comment_content: The main content of COMP 2011 is about the usage of C++. It is intended for students with basic programming background (such as the programming concepts in COMP 1021/1022P/1022Q). It will be an introduction to C++ object-oriented programming and data structures such as stacks, queues, linked lists, and binary trees. When you finish the learning of COMP 2011, you should have a basic backgroud of programming.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecturer of COMP 2011 is average. The teaching is clear but a little boring. And the learning experience in COMP 1022P is very useful. Some points would be skipped as it is assumed that you have the programming basis of java.
reviews.comment_grading: Because of the socail influence during the 19-20 fall semester, I chose the passing grading. So there is no experience of the grading.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is large, even though it is a 4 credit course. The assignments are very demanding. You have to spend a lot of time on the three assignments in the semester. The midterm is hard and checking paper is very important. Because of the socail influence during the 19-20 fall semester, the final exam is turned into assignment 4. So there is no experience of final exam.

reviews.author: Kevin KAI
reviews.title: A little bit challenging
reviews.comment_content:
The course is a little bit difficult to follow and understand. Especially the part after pointer.
COMP1022P may just require you to know programming and how to use it. Starting from COMP2011, you should know how to develop your own logic to use the programming knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: Could explain things logically and clearly. But the voice is not clear enough. A little bit soft, so sometimes cannot totally follow what she said.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is good.
In the first quiz, I get 21/24, just around the mean of the class.
About the lab, I get full mark in every lab. Some labs are challenging than you think. Not as easy as that before.
About the Assignment, since due to those men in black, this semester we cancelled the final exam and had 4 assignment, which are count 6 marks, 8 marks, 10 marks and 10 marks respectively. The first assignment is easy and the other 3 assignments are all challenging. You need to think and spend a long time to do that.
The first assignment is about array. I only get 85/100. The mean is 86/100.
The Second assignment is about function, especially the wide use of recursion. I get 100/100. The mean is about 80 something.
The third assignment is about structure, pointer and linked list. I get 66/100 because of the memory leak. The mean is only 55/100.
The 4th assignment is about class and linked list. I get 95/100. This time I check memory leak very very carefully. The mean is 70 something.
Midterm: Midterm addressed more to test your ability about develop your own programming with your own logic. So many  long questions. I get 86/100. The mean is 70 something.
Finally, my grade is A-. Very satisfying.
reviews.comment_workload: Large workload. I think I spend 50% above time to do COMP2011 things in the whole semester.

reviews.author: etyt
reviews.comment_content: The following topics are taught: basic, control, array, recursion, structure, function, cpp-11 features, scope, separate-compilation, file input & output, string, pointer, class, stack and queue. Although some of them were not included in the exam, still they are all very useful. For me, things go crazy when using pointer because it is a rather complicated thing and when deleting all pointers using a loop, you have to be very careful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia is a very nice lecturer. She is willing to answer every students' question. In the lessons, the content was quite well explained, with sufficient examples and sample programmes.
Meanwhile, most of the students in the class didn't attend the lectures after the midterm, as all the lectures were recorded.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade distribution (normal):
Quiz (in mid-September): 5%
Lab (10 sessions, not counting the mark of the worst two): 10%
Midterm: 25%
Assignment (3, not equally weighted):24%
Exam: 36%

Due to the suspension of teaching, 1 more assignment (10%) was added and the exam was cancelled. So the total score of the course became 74 marks.

I think my grade is reasonable. I performed quite badly in some of the assignments and so the grade is not very good (C+).
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was fine. Some students did their labs during the lab session but I prefer doing it before the lesson, so I could immediately show my programme to the TAs and go. But don't worry the labs are easy. The first two assignments were easy and I didn't use much time. The last two were so difficult for me and I even couldn't finish it. To be honest, I shall put more time on practising programming. The difficulty of the midterm was at the right level. Btw, some past papers will be provided on the course website.

reviews.comment_content:

The lecture notes and some good practice is all you need to get a good result in this course.
reviews.comment_grading: Generally, the grade is good, but you have to be very careful regarding anything that affects your grade. Since everything is relatively easy, you might be punished in grades for even some small mistakes.

This review will be written in terms of equivalent credit based on my general experience of courses of UST.
If you have experience in C/C++, the workload is around 1 credit.
If you don't, I think the workload is still below 3 credit.

reviews.author: Raiyan
reviews.comment_content:
BOOK used: The textbook is C++ For Everyone, 2nd Edition, Cay S. Horstmann

Pre-requisite: COMP 1021/1022P/1022Q or ISOM 3230. Exclusion: COMP 1003 / COMP 1004.

Topics:
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue
File input / output (not in exam)

Suggested IDE from the course : Eclipse
Software you may need: Valgrind (Learn linux), Terminal



* Pay attention and never leave out the smallest details. Usually, that's what they will test you with at the end.


Lecture notes are deceiving. It only demonstrates basic knowledge.
Do every labs and assignment and understand them well.


Use office hour even ever you can.

This year, the mid term exam was a variation of the assignments

*If you can use Loops then you can also use Recursion. So when you think of a problem, think about it in both the ways also learn to solve it both ways.




*** INFO used from the course website. https://course.cse.ust.hk/comp2011 ( Need user log in)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Somewhat boring but visiting during office hours are great. Teachers are really helpful and kind.

3 hours of lectures
2 hours of lab excercises
reviews.comment_grading:
There are TWO components that you must pass in order to pass the ENTIRE course.

quiz 5%
lab exercises 10%
programming assignments 24%
midterm exam 25%
final exam 36%

Super competitive, and you are against extremely hardworking students that can get 100 for everything.

Focus on actually understanding the concepts rather than your grades. You ll get higher grades that way.

Compete against yourself, not others. Looking at others will only intimidate you and you ll get bad grades doing that.
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty high, you have something to do every week.

if youre at ust then you can forget about free time if you wanna do great.

Its good tho because it really teaches you the content by doing.

Disastrous. DO NOT trust anyone saying that the grading is good. NO, it isn't. If you get mean, you get B-/C+.

Assignments get -10% penalties if there is memory leak.
Do self tests (on the course page) before exams. Study previous labs also.
This is a C++ course, so is your final grade (C+).

Do ask them about assignments if you can.

reviews.author: Justin Li
reviews.title: Work-Intensive Programming Course
reviews.comment_content:
This courses teaches all the basics about C++ programming and gives brief introduction to OOP (Object-oriented programming). Topics include Basic if-else logics, loops, functions, arrays, recursion, struct, pointers and class. Compared to CSE introductory 1000 courses, this course is much more advanced and demanding towards logical thinking and computation. The topics before mid-term exam are considerably basic while those afterwards are much more vague and complicated, especially with recursion and  pointers which are very logical.
Lab assignments are compulsory and follows closely the contents taught in lecture. Some lab assignments, especially with recursion and pointers quite difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chung was very familiar with the content yet many will find his lectures rather tedious and boring. Those who want interesting and interactive lectures may want to choose one taught by other professors.
All labs and lab assignments are personal work and not are taught by TAs, but they were very welcoming in solving questions and clarifying concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: The expectations of this course is high. The mid-term exam was relatively easy with mean around 65%. Meanwhile, only a few students were able to receive over 75% in the final exam, mean of around 45%, and by scoring 50% will get you B range because the final exam was simply very difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Because the way of examining in this course is very different from CSE introductory courses (from filling questions and blanks to writing whole length codes), it took quite a lot of time and work to get used to the style. Revising for vague and complicated topics like recursion and pointers required completing many past exam questions. This is not an easy course, and there is no work around it, so put more time and effort to get good results.

reviews.author: cwlimaa
reviews.comment_content: the difficulty is not the same for each semester

Midterm: 1.7sd
Final: 0.7sd
Letter Grade: A-

I feel like this course is just one of the more standard curve grading courses among all the courses I've taken so far in HKUST.

reviews.author: Jeff Sun
reviews.title: C++
reviews.comment_content: Basic pieces of stuff about C++. Watch as any subtle branch of the course may be covered unpredictably in the exams
reviews.comment_teaching: Another lecture that lulls me to sleep.
reviews.comment_grading:
Great! I messed up in final, getting embarrassing 67.5 but still got an A.
5% quiz, at the beginning of the semester.
3*8% programming assignments, throughout the semester, please do debug and confirm over and over again as one of my buddies messed up in assignment 2 and three, losing 4% of the course total. I also had a narrow escape in pa1, when their AI grader reported an error in compilation. It turned out that <cstdio> was automatically included in DEV C++ but they used eclipse. So use eclipse rather than anything else, it was so kind of the TA to have added back the marks for me or probably I will have a B range.
10% lab
25% midterm
36% final
'A' in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
Practice! I would suggest online judges besides going over the notes and programming assignments.
Take reviewing for exams seriously, the workload of the final review is supposed to large. Take my negative example in the messed up finals as I was surfing quora when I was supposed to review the details in the notes. Or I will have an A+, really regretful as I am...

reviews.author: PAINFUL JJ
reviews.comment_content: There's a lot of  contents covered in the course. More practice are necessary instead of just reading the notes, especially for the topics like pointers/recursion.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor tried her best to explain the concepts and the usage of different coding skills. Even though sometimes there's some bug in the demo programs, overall the concepts are clearly explained. Professor is nice too, she always allows students to visit her office and ask questions, even without appointment.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is so-so.
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy without a doubt. To me it's worth more than 4 credits.

reviews.author: UA
reviews.title: Programming with C++
reviews.comment_content:
An introduction to programming as well as some parts of Object Oriented Programming.

C++ language taught with elements using pointers, structs, classes.
Different elements brought about to explain complicated programs.

A good base for higher level programming.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is very detailed and has extensive knowledge in the course.

Examples and other related materials were also covered by the prof.
The theme of the lectures included some childish materials, such as the use of Minions and Smurf, may come across as a bit redundant.
reviews.comment_grading:
Average grading. SD is generally high considering the number of students taking the course.

Obtaineed slightly below mean for midterm, just mean for finals, almost all labs done. Assignments were fairly ok. Obtained  C+/B- for the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 Lab per week. (10%)
2 classes per week all around 1.5 hours each.
3 assignments per semester (6%,8%,10%)
1 quiz per semester(5%)

Quite a lot of workload when considering the assignments as they can get hard. Would need to start early to obtain a good grade in assignments and lab.

Labs and assignments have a skeleton included to guide you through your program.

reviews.author: Mauricio
reviews.title: Minions spam
reviews.comment_content: An introduction to C++ programming mostly teaching the C part of it. There was a bit of objects, but the main focus was on pointers. A good introductory class in my opinion.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor teaches just ok but I feel the Minions theme of the class was pushed to absurdity with the professor wasting time by showing trailers during the class. It ended pretty much empty by the end of the semester.
reviews.comment_grading: Pretty average grading although not having a midterm and so much of the grade coming from quizzes and labs made the grade fully depend on final.
reviews.comment_workload: Most of the labs weren't difficult once one gets used to planing and writing skeleton code of each program. There were 10 labs in total and 3 quizzes.  It was also possible to get bonus points through extra features in lab assignments. B considering it is a 4 credit course.

reviews.author: odlid_gib
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers the basic of C++ like function, if--then--else, while loop, for loop, fileio (not examined), scope, struct, array,pointer etc.

It is quite easy for those who's logic are not bad.
reviews.comment_teaching: I didn't really pay attention in the lectures since i have learned C++ before. But one thing i can tell is that he speaks quite soft.
reviews.comment_grading: Most students studying this course will get full mark for the assignments and lab. Therefore, you will have to get a pretty high score to get an A in this course.

3 Assignments
   Usually takes 1 to 4 hours to finish depending on how skilled are
you

Lab every week
   Not hard

reviews.author: christ
reviews.comment_content: Content is manageable.  As much of a cliche it sounds, the topics in late semester would take some time to fully understand what is going on.
reviews.comment_teaching: Demonstrating code neatly by splitting the screen in half, having the source code on one side and output on the other side.  Willing to help students for their problems.  Rather responsive to questions on emails and in facebook group.
reviews.comment_grading:
For each lab, attendance is taken and accounts for lab marks. To get full marks for each one, you need to complete specific tasks.  
Assignments are graded automatically so make sure the program runs as specified in the requirements.
Quiz on fundamental programming knowledge at the start of the semester is rather easy.
Mid-term shouldn't be extremely hard, but expect same topic on multiple questions.
Final Exam mostly focus on parts taught in late semester.
reviews.comment_workload: Expected to complete lab work before going to each session.  Probably not going to have enough time to finish it within lab session unless you're extremely familiar with coding yourself.  You can go as soon as your labs are graded. Assignments are rather time consuming.  Got some restrictions as to what you cannot use.

reviews.author: Raymond Cheng
reviews.title: Very good content and teaching
reviews.comment_content:
The course teaches about the fundamentals of C++. Here is a snapshot of the syllabus:

Basics (main, namespace, data types, constants)
- Control (For loops, switch statements, enum)
- Functions (declare and call functions, pass by value & by reference, return by value & return by reference)
Struct
- Cpp11 new features (general initialization using {} list, range for statement, lambda expressions)
- Scope (File, function, block scope)
- Pointers
- Arrays
- Recursion
- Class

All of the content is very practical and up-to-date to modern C++. It helped me understand the entire syntax and how C++ works in general.

Everything starting from the basics until functions should be pretty fundamental and easy to understand if you have taken a previous CS introductory course.

Topics from Struct to Scope should be straightforward as well, just pay attention to the specific syntax and how the features are used and you should be fine.

Starting from pointers, things are getting slightly more difficult as you are expected to know how they relate to normal variables and arrays and memory manipulation. For the last few lectures, you need to know how all the concepts come together as you will be expected to implement them in the exams.

Overall the content is great and very appropriate.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is pretty articulate in explaining concepts that might be pretty difficult to understand at first. He makes things easier to comprehend and demonstrates a lot of code examples in class which will clarify a lot of things. He is also very open to any kind of questions in class, so definitely take the chance in class to ask questions you are not sure of.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is a bit harsh I would say. To my knowledge (not sure whether it is 100% accurate though), midterm mean is around 55 and final mean around 63, and you need at least 25 points above the mean to get an A. Getting the mean should be a B- or C+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is quite manageable. Every week, there will be a lab which you will have to complete a program that is already partly written for you. The labs are quite easy to complete but some, especially the later ones, might take some time.

Throughout the semester, you will also get project assignments to  do, around once per month. The assignments really demand some effort and time, so be prepared to spend more than a week on it, a few days if you have more familiarity with C++.

reviews.author: Jacky.Huang
reviews.title: Cornerstone on the road of programming
reviews.comment_content: This course covers concepts ranging from the most basic statement (control flow) to OOP introduction (class), while Pointer and C String are the most confusing. Lots of details to remember. You can never know whether you have really grasped them by labs and assignments but past exam paper. Even though you have learnt C++ before, attendance is personally highly recommended.
reviews.comment_teaching:
MAK is really a humorous professor. He always rephrased students' question in class, so that all students were clear what his was trying to explain.
Some additional knowledge out from slides was provided. Appropriate lecture pace, enjoyable class atmosphere.
Highly recommend to take his course.

quiz                           5%
lab exercises            10%
programming assignments     6% + 8% + 10%
       (bonus provided)
midterm exam          25%
final exam                36%


Personally, I managed to finish a bonus question but got 0 points. So I didn't do this any more.
Programming assignment should better take more ratio.

------------
For a student who have learnt C++ before, each lab takes around 0.5~1.5h, final assignment takes around 6h.

reviews.author: zack0617
reviews.comment_content: I have no idea why i want to write a review instead of studying for the upcoming final. but whatever. So after this course, basically you should be able to write and debug in C++, design and write some recusive function, implement a class from scratehes(this is a must), and write a cpp file containing most of the function definition of a program. In general, you would acquire the ability to write a program in cpp and solve some problems. The amount of content is appropriate for a 4 credit course.

Y will not be greater than 20.

reviews.comment_workload:
A lot, despite the11 labs throughout the semster, if you really want to write good program, you need to do a lot of practise. For example, you may go through other programmer's code to see how to wirte short and compact code. (disclaimer: not encourage you to copy and paste.) To be a good programmer, you may devote certain amount of time to learn some tricks behind the C++ features to write good program, and that's the workload I refer to.
Of course, if you enjoy learning programming, you won't find it tired and time-consuming.
But as a deadline fighter, i did a large amount of drilling in recursion and class 5 days before final, and i finally realize how my assignment 3 should be implemented. (lol)

reviews.comment_grading: grading is good if you can understand all the material in the course
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is only completing all the lab exercise and attend the lab class for around 15 to 30 minutes if you have done the exercise before the lab class. And also need to submit three assignments in this semester. However, the assignment needs to be accurate and fulfill all the requirement listed on the assignment instruction page so it is not easy to get full marks. Most of the time people can get full marks in lab as they have unlimited time to try and test.

reviews.author: Imp.
reviews.comment_content: Pretty useful skills of C++. Before Midterm, the context is relatively easy, which is mainly about basic C++ programming, such as array and functions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Brian explains examples pretty clearly. He follows both ppt and his own examples.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is not so good.

quiz 5%
lab exercises 10%
programming assignments 24% (6%, 8%, 10%)
midterm exam 25%
final exam 36%

There are also bonus points for assignments. However, they are really hard to get.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not so bad. One lab each week, which takes about 1-2 hours. There are three assignments. The first one is relatively easy, which takes about 3-4 hours. But the other two assignments may take more time.

reviews.author: badgirlriri
reviews.comment_content:
Basics to C++ including: operators, data types, basic syntax, control flow, functions, arrays, recursion, scope, struct, pointers, linked lists, dynamic data, class, stack/queue and file input/output.
Fun at the beginning, quite easy and interesting, starts to get a little more difficult after midterms.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia is good, but Brian is better. Cecia goes through examples in class, which is good but tends to not cover details which we would have needed to know as she doesn't strictly follow the slides. However, brian not only goes through slides, but also goes through examples. Both are very nice professors and will help you whenever you need it.
reviews.comment_grading:
On a curve, which is kind of inconvenient for non-experienced programmers as most of the students are comfortabel with most technques taught in the class.

Quiz 5%
Labs 10%
Assignments 24%
Midterm 25%
Final 36%

Quiz is super easy, 30 min MC. Labs occur every week, can finish from before and just go to lab for 20 mins to wait your turn for demo. Asignments, trickier, you get two weeks to complete, usually provided with a skeleton code. Midterm relatively easy. Final slightly difficult. Good thing is that since grading is so spread out, everything doesn't depend on final.

Tip- Doing the self-tests on the comp 2011 course website helps a ton.
reviews.comment_workload: Somewhat heavier, as the major chunk of the grading is focused on the project based material. Lots to do during sem time. This might be inconvenient and time consuming, but at the end of the day, helps a lot with practice which is the most important part of programming. Pays of at the end.

reviews.author: Vinca
reviews.title: Interesting group work
reviews.comment_content:
The contents are quite easy at first if you have already know C++ languages before. Even though you only knew C language (like me), you can also handle the course quite well at first. So it is quite recommended to take COMP1029C first if you don't know anything in C++.
But things got much more difficult starting from function overloading and reach the peak at pointers. You really need to practice in order to be familiar and understand the things being taught.
It should be the basic things about programming, so should be useful in the future.
reviews.comment_teaching: She has accent. But that doesn't hinder her teaching. Personally, I think she taught quite well and explain everything very clearly especially when using graphs to teach pointers.
reviews.comment_grading:
My groupmates and I spent quite some time to strive for bonuses. And for all 3 quizzes I could got full marks.
The final exam is above mean about 1. something SD. So at last I could get A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
It really depends in this semester.
We are allowed to form group of two, to create a game in each week from scratch. Bonuses would be given to those with creative ideas and tidy, flexible programming works, and also sometimes special techniques.
If you are going to just finish the lab to get full mark, it should be very easy. But if you are striving for the bonuses, it would take quite some time. I had spent one whole week to finish one of the labs, from planning to implementing to debugging.
Forming group can also depend. It is not more people do better job when coming to programming. Combining codes can be very frustrating as different people have different style of programming. But I think it is a great experience overall.

reviews.author: Anguslee
reviews.comment_content: Mainly teaching the basic knowledge for C++ programming such as introduction to C++ object-oriented programming and data structures such as stacks, queues, linked lists, and binary trees.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor have provide the details explain of program running sequence. Also professor will use graphic presentation to explain how the program run in real situation
reviews.comment_grading: I think if you have view the past papers before the test it would be easy to get the b range
reviews.comment_workload: There will have 3 personal programming assignment and lab works in each lab. I think it would not be hard to handle it

reviews.author: dragoon
reviews.comment_content: About C++ content and basic programming knowledge.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teacher is quite passionate about the subject and he used minions throughout the course to try to make the course more interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is ok but some of the computer science students have a lot of background knowledge in the subject so make sure to practice more if you lack experience in c++ or programming in general.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is moderate. There is  a weekly lab that I had to preparation for in order to do the lab smoothly . I also had to read the lecture otes

reviews.author: JJ Lam
reviews.title: Good course if you have time to study by yourself
reviews.comment_content: The content is just like other programming courses, eg. loop, if-statement. The unique part of c++ maybe the â€˜pointerâ€™ part
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor has full passion to teach the course as he uses minions as the theme to make the lab assignement in order to make it more interesting(he is super fans of minions lol). He spends a lot of time to explain some complicated concept, eg pointer and he is super nice to solve any problem you ask.
reviews.comment_grading: Basically you can get full mark for all lab assignments given that you spend time on that and you may ask TAs for help. Also, 3 quiz are not super difficult that you can really get full mark for all of them. Final exam is quite challenging that really test your understanding on the concept, but just try your best. Grading is nice as I got an A while achieving 90.5% in the overall course only.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite heavy, especially I dont really have a programming background as a BBA student. You better read the notes every lecture to get a sense, otherwise you cant understand the lectures afterwards

reviews.author: Edm
reviews.title: Do not take this course for free electives
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to computer programming
C++ basics: basic syntax, data types, operators
Control flow
Functions
Array and structure
Recursion
Scope
Struct
Pointers
Dynamic Data
Class
Stack and Queue
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor speaks in a fast-pace but understandable, which is good. However, he focused on his programming console throughout the lectures which made the class atmosphere uncomfortable for non-CS major students. I skipped most of the lectures except those having in-class quizzes because of that.

The course adopted a new syllabus which focused on students' creativity on programming, making it unideal for students who want to learn more about computer science but not programming.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Lab exercises 40% (10 total, 4% each)
Mean almost 100%
Quizzes 15% (In-class, open-book, 3 total, 5% each)
Mean: 84.1/100 (SD 19.3), 87.5/100 (SD 11.8), 74.1/100 (SD 20.0) (exclude zeros)
Final Exam 45% (Open-book)
Mean 56.2/100, SD 18.4 (exclude zeros)

The course grade was curved in a ridiculous way, I got almost full marks on labs, below mean on quizzes and below mean on final (~50%), total score was about 68-69%, final grade was a C.
A friend of mine literally scored more than half of my final exam scores (~25-30%), and he got the same grade as me (C). This is totally unfair as the final exam was the biggest deciding factor, the curve was not correlated to the final exam at all, which does not make any sense. I am actually rather disappointed and frustrated when receiving the grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are lab exercises weekly, which takes on average 4-5 hours to complete, however some labs involving pointers, linked lists are quite challenging, these would take several days to complete. So most of us have to finish the lab exercises before the lab as lab problems are posted online a week before. I personally skipped most of the lab sections and submitted the exercises on Canvas.
Quizzes are not heavy loads for me as I gave up all of them and all in final instead.
The final exam is quite challenging so it takes much time to prepare for. As I had the MATH 2033 exam one day before, there was not too much time to prepare the exam for the COMP 2011 and I suffered from it.
In all, the workload of the course is quite heavy, especially for labs involving higher-level knowledge such as pointers and linked lists.

reviews.comment_teaching:
very bad. He is boring and just read from ppt. No interaction at all.
Sometimes you can't even understand him. He did't even explain the details clearly.
worst professor ever.

Very bad.

reviews.author: Ashim
reviews.title: Review
reviews.comment_content:
At the beginning of the course the content is very easy due to which i got exceptional score in my quiz but later the content starts getting harder.
The content are as following:
1. Pointers
2. Functions
3. Array (2D,3D)
4. Struct
5. Linked List
6. Queue (not asked in exam)
7. Stack (not asked in exam)
8. Class (basic further taught in COMP 2012)

The contents are useless for exam because even though you know the concept you wont be able to do well in exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Our teacher was Cecilia and she tried her best to teach us. I already knew much of the concept so i cant judge much on her teaching.
For the Lab TA's, my TA was Kevin and he was very helpful. He would answer my question even via email during non office hours which helped alot.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grades are distributed as below.
1. Quiz (5%)
2. Mid term ( 25%)
3. Assignment ( 24 %)
4. Lab ( 10%)
5. Final (36%)

The quiz is during the beginning of the semester and quite easy if you have some back ground as not much has been taught.

The Mid term is like a final exam because the paper is for 2 hours and the full mark for the paper is 100. In our batch the mean was 54 which is quite low. The paper was quite tough.

The first Assignment is 5% and is quite easy. The second asssignment is 9% which is hard and the final assignment is worth 10% which is the hardest of them all.
reviews.comment_workload: The work load at the beginning of the semester is quite low but it increases exponentially. The labs get harder as you reach towards the end. The first assignment is quite easy and you will think all of them will be easy but thats not the case. The assignments get way harder later. The worst thing about the assignment is that you will have to do labs simultaneously with the assignments. If you have two weeks to do an assignment that means in those two weeks you will have to do two labs as well. As i mentioned earlier the labs get quite harder later so it consumes time as well. I think the work load is quite high for this course.

reviews.author: alexs
reviews.comment_content:
The content is not difficult. The hardest part of the course is about pointer.

Nearly all labs need much time to do so as those labs require a good understanding of C++. New skills which are not out of the lecture may involve.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Course instructor is good. She taught clear concept of C++. She can give many examples for us to understand most of the features.

Lab TAs are also helpful if you have some question to ask. They usually can help you figure out and solve your problem.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. Overall get mean may get a C+ to B range. Work hard on exam and assignment is helpful.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 simple all mc quiz
1 midterm
3 assignment, pa 3 is the most difficult which is about pointer
Many labs which need time to do

Spare more time to do is the key to reduce the workload

reviews.author: yusless
reviews.title: Decent course (if you work hard for it)
reviews.comment_content:
The content is quite simple, but the exam requires you to have thorough understanding of the course materials and C++ in general to obtain a good grade

A lot of labs require lots of thinking and understanding behind the task given to code a solution on that task. Time consuming if you aren't too familiar with the lab tasks.

Quiz is quite basic, just need a good understanding of C++ in general. Midterms and exams are similar to labs in the way that you have to code solutions to given problems on the fly as the exam progresses, with extra emphasis on overall content learnt in 2011 for the exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not much to say regarding lab instructors as I have not really asked them questions, but they will explain about some of the more difficult lab assignments during the lab sessions.

Course instructor was ok. She can give you some insight in some problems you may not have thought about, so I think it is still worth coming to lectures. It's not a must to attend lectures as lecture videos tend to be provided for the course.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. The exam might be quite difficult, but it really depends on the student whether they have a good understanding of C++ and course materials and whether they have the ability to formulate solutions to given code problems on the fly.
reviews.comment_workload:
Lots of labs to do, with varying difficulties. Not easy as you could be spending hours debugging a single thing.

The assignments are alright, with the last one being the most difficult. Again, you need a good understanding of C++ to truly be able to write elegant solutions for it, like recursion.

reviews.author: cshime
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers most of the basic contents of c++ and contains some simple data structures. Covered topics are follows:
1. Basic syntax, operators and data types
2. If-else and switch statements
3. Array and functions
4. Scope of identifiers
5. Recursion
6. File I/O (Skip in 2017 fall)
7. String Class (Skip in 2017 fall)
7. Struct and Classes
8. C++ 11 new features
9. Pointers
10. Stack and queue
The contents are important for the upcoming courses with COMP2011 as pre-requisite. Most difficult part would be recursion and pointers as it takes lots of time to understand the logic behind when doing assignments or the final exam paper.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good lecturers and TAs as they are always available to answer several questions after the class.
They created a Facebook group page for us to raise different questions and discuss several concepts freely with TAs and some lecturers monitoring. In fact, they answered almost all the questions even if the questions contains some out-of-course contents.
reviews.comment_grading:
In 2017 fall, the grading proportion divides as:
5% quiz
11% Lab attendence (with 11 labs)
24% assignments (6+8+10)
24% midterm
36% final
The grading would not be too tough, A range was not too difficult to get if you get about 90% with your total grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is normal for me. There has total eleven lab assignments each week and three assignments through out this semester. They are not difficult if you really pay efforts in class.

reviews.author: mysam
reviews.comment_content: This course covers almost the basics of c++, including control flows, array, functions, pointers and class. Also it covers some simple data structures like stack/ queue and linked list. The most difficult part would be pointers. Make sure you fully understand the concept of pointers before having exam as it takes relatively large proportion in the paper.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecturers and TAs show very high teaching quality. They explain the concept very clearly and comprehensively. They also create a Facebook group for students to ask questions and discuss freely.
reviews.comment_grading: The course includes weekly lab exercises, one quiz at the early of the semester (around week 3), 3 homework (basic c++/ recursion/pointer), one mid-term exam and of course final exam. Mid-term + final exam is around 50% of the total grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not so high if you already have some programming concepts and knowledge. In average you will need 1 hr for lab ex., 3-4 hrs for each hw. You may need extra working time if you are poor in recursion. Take times read descriptions carefully.

reviews.author: Camel
reviews.comment_content: About the beginning of C++ and end with how to implement linked list with pointer, basic of Class.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She try her best to let the lecture become interesting but the course material is boring. So there are not many people attend the lecture

Provide in-class example for students to follow. Demonstrate the code with real-time program.

If you have some background in programming, the first half of the lecture is quite boring
reviews.comment_grading:
Generous to people who have work hard
Contain mid-term, assignments, labs, final exam.
Final exam contribute 60% of the grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Have assignments 1, 2, 3
1 lab per week no break

Each assignment require more and more time and difficulty increased  1 by 1.

reviews.author: FKLFKL
reviews.comment_content:
If you take the 1029C, you can revise less for the mid-term as many of the content overlapped.
After the mid-term, pointers will be the focus. You can do well in the final exam if you go through all the lecture notes and memorize some of the algorithms and the past papers.
reviews.comment_teaching: Cecia is a good instructor. Her English is fluent and she would tell jokes in the class. She is also willing to answer student's questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
For the grading scheme, you can refer to the other review.
I got 94 in the mid-term and 79 in the final exam, full marks in all homework and labs, 21/25 in the quiz, A+ finally so I think the grading in A range is good.
reviews.comment_workload:
As a physics student, the workload is heavy comparatively. You have to finish a lab every week, 3 homework assignments and also keep on revising the materials so that you can refresh you memory and  don't have to do revision overnight before the mid-term and final exams. But your hard work will pay off.
BTW you will learn what is ã€Œä¼ã€in a TA's hw whose surname starts with a letter 'Y'.

reviews.author: Sunny0516
reviews.title: Fundamental CS course
reviews.comment_content:
This course will teach fundamental CS and OOP concepts by using C++, including functions / array / scope / structures / pointer / class / stack and queue / new C++11 features (added this semester).

For pointers, we have to learn about linked lists too, and of course these will come along with recursion (functions), dynamic array, memory allocation and leakage.

The regular 11 labs were about:
1 - Basic C++
2 - Basic I/O
3 - Nested Loops
4 - 1D array
5 - 2D array
6 - Recursion
7 - File I/O and string (not accessed in final exam)
8 - Structures
9 - Pointer
10 - Dynamic array and linked list
11 - Classes

Midterms accessed you from basic C++ to functions (recursion, overload, pass by reference, declaration and definition)

Final accessed everything except file I/O, C++ strings and queue structure type.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Cecia is one of the best tutors I have ever met. She can teach many things not mentioned on lecture notes, which is helpful for you to clear concepts. She will also demonstrate and explain about the examples given on lecture notes (which unfortunately lacked explanation)

After lessons, students could still approach her easily. You can even find her after lesson times to ask about this course's materials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme is as follows:
Quiz at beginning of semester: 5%
Regular lab practice every week: 10%
Programming assignments * 3: 24% (6+8+10)
Midterm: 25%
Final Exam: 36%


Quiz: Full Mark 25, Mean 20.00, SD 2.91.

Lab: Basically everyone got full marks.

PA: Most people got 80 or above for the 3 assignments. The guidelines were not given explicitly, but as long as you follow the requirements strictly, you should be able to get fair marks for the 3 assignments.

Midterm: Mean 60.1, SD 18.5. 4 past papers from recent years will be given on the course site, which can allow you to preview what to expect in the exam. The exam was not too difficult, and people could get up to 99/100 marks in this semester.

Final: Mean 55.4, SD 22.0. Similar to midterms, you can get 4 past papers from recent years too. You were given 3 hours to complete 11 questions (first question consist of 10 T/F parts), and questions related to pointers / linked lists were fairly difficult.



The grading was quite fair I think. I got 92.5% (above 1.8 SD in midterm, 1.7 SD in final) in total and resulted in A+; people claimed that getting above mean can already give you a B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload for this course is quite large, even for a 4 credit course. There are 3 PAs, 11 labs, midterm and final exam for this course.

For the first 3-4 labs, you only have to spend around 30 minutes each, but for the later labs, you may end up spending above 1 day to complete the lab, which was a waste of time. However, as the coding for the labs would not be checked, many people ended up copying others' code for the regular labs.

For the 3 PAs, the difficulty grew exponentially - the first PA was fairly easy and could be finished in 2 hours, while the 3rd PA took me more than 3 days to finish.

You had to go through all lecture notes thoroughly for the midterm and final exam.

reviews.author: RR***
reviews.comment_content:
intro to c++
so it's said the contents are not so hard, however, still quite not easy to understand for beginners, need preview, listen carefully in class and review, if you don't have any background. basics in the first month, array and functions in the second month, and after midterm there will be structures, pointers and class
reviews.comment_teaching:
very nice instructor
like students ask questions and answer kindly
reviews.comment_grading:
you will earn what you deserve
midterm is easy however final is hard, recursion is important for both exams
reviews.comment_workload:
workload very heavy
assignment is so hard

reviews.author: Seeking4u()
reviews.title: Intro to C++
reviews.comment_content: Overall just introductory topic on C++, will not go too deep or mind-blowing in the lecture notes (unfortunately). Might be a little bit overwhelming to those who are new to C++ programming language. I'd say recursion, pointer, and class are the most trickiest topics. Spend more time studying them.
reviews.comment_teaching: Went to almost every lecture, the instructor explains those concepts in a rather slow-paced manner. She will elaborate more on those C++ topics if you approach her afterwards. Overall nice and friendly.
reviews.comment_grading:
quiz: 5%
lab: 10%
programming assignments: 24% (3 of them, 7% + 7% + 10%)
midterm: 25%
final: 36%

Some statistics:
final: mean = 63.35/100 with SD = 23.38
midterm: mean = 72.85/100 with SD = 18.22
quiz: mean = 22.02/25 with SD = 2.53
PA1: mean = 38.18/40 with SD = 5.8
PA2: mean = 91.7/100 with SD = 18.6
PA3: mean = 93.97/100 with SD = 14.68

24 in the quiz, 99 in the midterm, 93 in the final, full mark in all lab tasks and programming assignments yield A+, urban legend says that COMP 2011 in spring semester is generally easier and gives better grading in comparison to fall semester version.
reviews.comment_workload:
10 lab tasks and 3 programming assignments, as well as attending the lectures and practicing C++. Spent quite an amount of time studying for this course.
All the lab tasks are released either on late Friday or during the weekend, it's okay to finish the lab task before actually attending the lab session, so if you want to have more time to prepare for the lab session, you can register for lab sessions on Thursday or Friday. Note that sometimes the lab tasks can be very annoying to debug.
For the programming assignments, always start early, this saves you from last-minute-debugging-headache.

reviews.author: helloitdog
reviews.title: Not bad?
reviews.comment_content:
C++ Basics
Control Flow
Function
Array
======[MT]=====
RECURSION [DIFFICULT]
C++11 [NEW]
Scope/Separate Compilation
STRUCT + POINTER [EXTREMELY DIFFICULT]
Stack and Queue (Queue is out syllabus for finals)
The absolute fundamental class for COMP students. You'll find most COMP/CPEG students in this class as it's required.
The teaching can be improved by giving us more time to practice and digest on difficult topics as stated above.
reviews.comment_teaching: Registered for class of Dr. Cecia Chan. Skipped a lot of lessons but regretted since later topics are quite hard to get a grasp. Solely by reading the ppts will get you confused. Go to Programming Commons if you have any questions

reviews.comment_workload:
Weekly labs, as usual
3 PAs
PA1: Tic-Tac-Toe
PA2: Recursive game
PA3: Struct and Pointers utilisation

Advised to learn basic linux for debugging/memleak checking (I personally don't know how to use the linux interface to check for bugs and got a memleak in PA3 which I lost some marks)

reviews.author: CS
reviews.comment_content: The Lecture Notes is well organised. Also, It provides a new C++ features like lamda. The  content is no different compares with the previous lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Brian Mak is a good teacher.He is a well prepared for the course. He also speaks a good English and explain the idea clearly. He uses the IPad and Apple Pencil during the class. I think it is his teaching style.
reviews.comment_grading: Actually, this is not a good grade course. the instructor follows the school grading reference. That means getting an A range is very difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: There are eleven labs , three project assignments, one midterm and one final exam. Workload depends on your sense of programming. The recursion task is difficult and consuming a lot of time. As a 4 credits course. the workload is quite heavy.

reviews.author: Xelopie
reviews.comment_content: It's easy if you have learned C/C++ before. It's about C++ for beginners. Just some basic stuff like pointers, if, while loop, etc. The lab work is not so hard as well.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think Andrew is a great instructor. He is good at explaining the ideas of different lines. He was also humorous so that we were always given some funny videos to enjoy at the end of the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: On average, I think it is not good in grading. You need to reach almost 80% in order to get a B+/B (the mean is usually around 70%) If you get a final score around the mean, you probably will only get C+.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 assignments and 10 labs in 1 semester. The first 2 assignments nearly spent me half day for each of them. The final one took me 1 whole day to figure it out and also debug. The lab work was much more easier. If you have enough experience, you can figure it out very fast. So generally speaking, not so much to do in this course.

reviews.author: MEMENTO
reviews.comment_content: The most important and difficult content about this course was about how pointers works in cpp. cpp is quite similar to java in many ways, so if you took Comp1022P, you would have edge to the others. Other contents include basic data types, struct, some simple data structures like stack and queue etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Cecia's lecture was pretty straightforward and clear, and the TAs were also quite helpful during the lab section.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was quite fair. Even if you get slightly below 1SD on both mid-term and final, you can get A if you get 100% mark on all the assignments, which is not that difficult.
Grading Scheme:
midterm-25%
final-36%
quiz-5%
lab attendence-10%
3 Assignments- 24%
reviews.comment_workload: Workload was not much. There are three assignments to do, each of which you can probably finish within 2-3 days, and the weekly lab assignment is not too heavy.

reviews.author: David Mak
reviews.comment_content:
This course assumes that students have already taken any of the COMP1000 prerequisite courses, and gives students a week to bridge the gap between Python/Java/Excel VBA before starting with C++.

The course will cover aspects of the C++ programming language from basic conditional logic to pointers and classes. Lecture notes are often very comprehensive and additional material will be distributed to aid students.

Alternate Course Title: Introduction to C++ Programming Language
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Chan is very concise when explaining concepts in general, and she will spend extra time and effort on relatively more difficult concepts (e.g. pointers). She will also spend time after class to try answer questions from students.

The Lab TAs are also very kind and helpful. They will try to explain the goal and approach to the assignments concisely.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% Quiz
10% Lab Exercise
24% Homework assignment
25% Midterm
36% Final

You must not miss the 10% from lab exercises. Missing one session could be the difference of half a grade. (I learned this the hard way)

Homework assignment is also score high, as there will be some test cases already provided.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload throughout the semester is fairly average, and there is generally no prior reading before class. However, students are expected to be very familiar with the concepts in the exams, and thus workload will exponentially increase during examination periods.

You may consider workload as 'B' if you are a highly motivated individual, or you have prior experience in programming.

reviews.author: Tim
reviews.comment_content:
The course taught C++ from the beginning, so it didn't require any C++ knowledge beforehand.

The lectures notes contained many sample codes, which were very useful for understanding the coding.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Albert discussed each topic in great details. His explanation was very clear and straightforward.

Although his voice was constantly flat, he did try to make his lecture interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: Really good grade. A range if you have overall 90% score.
reviews.comment_workload:
Nearly none, except for the assignments. The 3 assignments took quite a lot of time to finish. But they were assigned months ago, so there were sufficient time.

Lab is not compulsary.
